urn:contentItem:5WGF-0KP1-JCMN-Y04B-00000-00Android creator Andy Rubin is accused of running a 'sex ring' (GOOG, GOOGL)2019-07-03T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:11:50ZLexisNexisAndroid creator Andy Rubin is accused of running a 'sex ring' (GOOG, GOOGL)Nick Bastone

Jul 03, 2019( The Business Insider: http://www.businessinsider.com/ Delivered by Newstex) Flickr/Joi Ito Further details about Andy Rubin's alleged extramarital affairs were revealed in unsealed court documents on Tuesday, shedding new light on last year's New York Times report[1] which claimed the Android creator had been involved in "ownership relationships" with multiple women. One woman, who is referred to in the complaint as "M," was allegedly working with Rubin in what was described as a "sex ring." "M" would "agree to perform various sexual acts with multiple men," have it filmed for "the enjoyment of Rubin and other men," and then, would have sex with Rubin "off-camera," according to the complaint. Also, central to the complaint is the accusation that Rubin cheated his former wife out of a lot of money with a prenuptial agreement that didn't cover some of his personal wealth — and that may have been drafted by an attorney with a conflict of interest.

Visit Business Insider's homepage for more stories[2]. Android creator Andy Rubin was allegedly involved in running a "sex ring" with at least one woman, and is accused of cheating his ex-wife out of millions of dollars in their prenuptial agreement, according to a civil complaint unsealed on Tuesday in connection with another case. The documentswere first shared by Buzzfeed News' Ryan Mac[3]. A lawyer for Rubin says that the complaint is full of "false claims." "This is a family law dispute involving a wife who regrets her decision to execute a prenuptial agreement. It is full of false claims and we look forward to telling our side of the story," a lawyer for Rubin told Business Insider. Read more: Larry Page 'bypassed' Alphabet's board to personally give Andy Rubin a $150 million stock package while he was under investigation for sexual misconduct, according to lawsuit[4] In the unsealed complaint, one woman, who is referred to as "M," was allegedly working with Rubin in what the filing describes as a "sex ring." "M" would "agree to perform various sexual acts with multiple men," have it filmed for "the enjoyment of Rubin and other men," and then, would have sex with Rubin "off-camera," according to the documents. The details regarding Rubin's alleged extramarital affairs shed new light on last year's New York Times report[5] which claimed the Android creator had been involved in "ownership relationships" with multiple women during his marriage. According to the complaint, Rubin would "pay for their expenses in exchange for offering them to other men." Central to the complaint is the accusation that Rubin cheated Rie Rubin, his now-former wife, out of a lot of money by having her sign a prenuptial agreement days before their wedding, while she was pregnant with their child, without adequately disclosing that his lawyer had represented him in a previous divorce. That conflict of interest, as well as the rest of the story, form a basis for invalidating the agreement, Rie Rubin argues in the complaint. With the complaint, Rie Rubin is seeking to invalidate that prenuptial agreement, with which she says that Rubin was able to exclude some of his personal assets from being covered by the agreement — including what appears to be his portion of the proceeds from the sale of Rubin's previous company Danger to Microsoft in 2008[6]. Specifics of that deal were redacted in the documents. However, the documents say that Rubin's net worth went from about $10.3 million at the time of their marriage, up to an estimated $350 million today. Last fall, when news broke that Google paid Rubin a $90 million exit package despite multiple cases of harassment reportedly having been brought against him, a major controversy was stirred internally at the tech giant. Some 20,000 employees worldwide staged a walkout in protest of Rubin's payout and the company's overall handling of harassment cases, especially amongst executives. At the time, Google CEO Sundar Pichai said[7] that over the previous two years, 48 employees had been fired for sexual misconduct, 13 of whom held senior positions at the company. Read the full complaint here: NOW WATCH: Google finally revealed Stadia pricing, games, and release date[8]See Also: The Alphabet arm tasked with fighting online harassment and extremism has reportedly cultivated a toxic work culture of its own[9]'How does Google Photos work?': Everything you need to know about Google's photo storage app for iPhone and Android[10]Alphabet's cybersecurity urn:contentItem:5VNF-JDV1-F03R-N2T0-00000-00Android Q tries to address Google's biggest dilemma - data privacy2019-03-17T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:11:49ZLexisNexisAndroid Q tries to address Google's biggest dilemma - data privacyKarthekayan Iyer

Mar 17, 2019( BGR: Your Mobile Life: http://www.bgr.in Delivered by Newstex) As you read this, Google is being probed for its business practices[1] somewhere around the world. In the past few years, Margrethe Vestager, a Danish politician and European Commissioner for Competition, has fined Google and in the process, found how the company is too big and tends to be a data broker. The hyper connected world that we live in is almost impossible to imagine without Google. It provides mail (read: Gmail), mapping solution (read: Google Maps), photo sharing platform (read: Google Photos), and others.

It is the developer of world's biggest mobile platform (read: Android), and holds the key to the biggest video platform (read: YouTube). If Microsoft[2] was synonymous with the desk, then Google is synonymous with your pocket. Whether you use an Android or an iPhone, there is Google involved in it somehow. Even if you don't use any Google product then some other product could be powered by Google's Cloud service. Despite all the record fines being imposed on it, Google[3] has often challenged those verdicts. The company which has a corporate motto of 'Don't be Evil' sometimes makes you wonder whether it is evil or not. Setting Google's business practices aside for a moment, it needs to be noted that you cannot do a lot of things without giving consent to Google. An easier example is Google Maps, which gives directions from point A to point B by recording your GPS location and it does so, after explicitly taking consent. The unanswered question is whether it stops recording your location after you reached your destination and turned off location services. I'm not trying to justify Google here and in fact, I would want them to be more stringent with the way they handle user data, whether it's on Gmail, Google Maps or Android and this week, we saw some signs of it. https://www.bgr.in/how-to/how-to-install-android-q-developer-beta-on-all-google-pixel-devices-right-now/ Also Read How to install Android Q Developer Beta on all Google Pixel devices right now[4] On Thursday, Google announced the first developer beta of Android Q[5] for its Pixel smartphones. The beta comes even as the company struggles to update the Android distribution numbers for nearly five months now. The beta arrives at a time when most popular smartphones are running at least two generation old version or Android and have little or no opportunity to get the taste of newest flavor of Android. Nevertheless, it shows what Google aims to do with software for the year ahead and most importantly, shows that privacy is an issue it aims to tackle directly. Android Q addresses privacy issues becomes clear by seeing that new iPhone and, where Apple argues that privacy matters. When you install Android Q for the first time on any of the three generations of Pixel smartphones, you will not notice much difference. In fact, the UX is so similar that Google didn't even bother to put an Easter egg. There are signs of Q only at the start screen and in About Phone section. But when you look at Settings menu, there are two profound changes - location and privacy now have dedicated sections. When you tap on them, they are filled with options that are there in current builds of Android Pie. But a leaked build of Android Q[6] hints at a 'Privacy Dashboard' that will let you tackle permission distribution in the form of charts and graphs. Since this is just the first beta and there are reportedly plans for five to six betas before the final release, we could see this feature in future builds.   https://st1.bgr.in/wp-content/uploads/2019/03/Android-Q-screen-recording-intext.jpg Image Credit: Rehan Hooda Also, when you open camera app for the first time after installing Android Q beta, you will see a revamped permission setting. Android 9 Pie[7] presented a singular option for location access with options for allow and deny. With Android Q, it changes for good with three different options: Allow, allow only while the app is in use and Deny. The granular option shows how Google will let other apps apart from its own to get user location on Android going forward. In theory, Facebook or Foursquare won't be able to collect your location when you are not using them. It needs to be seen whether that translates into real world use case considering how some apps have been found to use different methods to break the rules. Google has already spoken a great deal about data privacy with Android Q release. One of the leaked AOSP builds showed Google planning to add a real-time notification that would show which apps are using sensitive information such as location. It is not here yet but when it becomes available with future build, Google will only further bridge the gap in privacy practice with iOS, Apple[8]'s mobile operating system. Google is also expected to impose tighter background restrictions, meaning apps will not be able to launch activities in the background. A lot of these measures will not only improve the health of user privacy on Android, but it will also improve battery life.Watch: Android Q How to Install A lot of changes that we are seeing in the very first build of Android Q and the big changes that could arrive in the future build might have to do with the sentiment around the company. Big tech companies, be it Google or Facebook or Amazon, are in the crosshairs of politicians around the world, for their inability to curb misinformation and apparent powers in their respective industry. Some officials even wonder if these companies are monopolies in their individual business domains and lack of competition indicates they are. With Europe passing GDPR (General Data Protection Regulation), individuals now have more control over how their data is collected and processed by these tech companies. Data is at the center of everything these tech companies do and access to more data will only make them more powerful as they build Artificial Intelligence[9] into all their services and AI is basically a machine that needs to learn and process data to get better. Privacy is the fundamental right of every person in this world and tech companies should find a way to explicitly get approval before collecting them. The very first build of Android Q shows Google is listening and that is a good start. Actions speak louder than words and, in this case, Google seems to be adopting actions while Menlo Park-headquartered Facebook seems like all words.   https://st1.bgr.in/wp-content/uploads/2019/03/Android-Q-screenshot-intext.jpg Image Credit: Rehan Hooda Apart from privacy, Google has taken tiny steps to match some seamless features available on iOS. For instance, there is now an option to enable native screen recording from within feature flags in developer options. The Now Playing audio now appears on the always on display while notification shade shows how long the device will last instead of just the battery percentage. One annoying change is when you take screenshot on Android Q, Google takes form of native display, meaning it retains the notch and the screenshots on Pixel 3 XL are downright ugly[10]. I think Google will revert to older screenshot and is probably playing with users. Every change within Android Q seems small but they are significant. They will make the user experience rich, but I fear that all this goodness will be restricted to Google's own Pixel smartphones. urn:contentItem:5PGD-9791-DXH2-62JM-00000-00Andy Weissman is interviewed on Bloomberg TV.2017-09-13T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:11:49ZLexisNexisBLOOMBERG TV12:00 AM ESTAndy Weissman, Julia Chatterley, Joe WeisenthalNEWSInternational091376cb.550Andy Weissman is interviewed on Bloomberg TV.Julie Hyman

Andy Weissman discusses the economy and technology.

(This is not a legal transcript. Bloomberg LP cannot guarantee its accuracy.)

ANDY WEISSMAN, PARTNER, UNION SQUARE VENTURE, IS INTERVIEWED ON BLOOMBERG TV

SEPTEMBER 13, 2017

SPEAKERS: ANDY WEISSMAN, PARTNER, UNION SQUARE VENTURE

JULIA CHATTERLEY, BLOOMBERG NEWS

JOE WEISENTHAL, BLOOMBERG NEWS

JULIE HYMAN, BLOOMBERG NEWS

[*] JULIE HYMAN, BLOMBERG HOST: What'd You Miss? Well, Andy Weissman of Union Square Ventures focuses on early stage investments in the internet, services and information technology sectors. And he is today in the Bloomberg Sooner Than You Think conference at Cornell Tech's new campus on Roosevelt Island. He has been talking about New York City as a technology hub. It has sort of been maybe in the shadow of Silicon Valley to some extent, but certainly has pretty robust presence. Andy, thank you for joining us. Now, when you look at New York and Silicon Valley is sort of opposite poles on the opposite coast here, they do have some similarities, certainly in the terms of costs. So do you find now that New York is not just competing with California but competing with other locations around the country to a larger extent?

ANDY WEISSMAN, PARTNER, UNION SQUARE VENTURE: Well, I think part of the question is how you define competition and in this case I think each region can be unique, New York is clearly unique, it's different than Silicon Valley. And so I find the competition between New York and Silicon Valley to be a bit of a nothing burger if you will.

JOE WEISENTHAL, BLOOMBERG HOST: Well, framing it from a geographical perspective, obviously, one of the big stories in the economy right now is the extraordinary dominance and influence of the major players in tech, your Amazons, Facebooks, Alphabets, Apples, I think that's them. And the difficulty that people -- that companies are having in competing with them, we have seen how snap, for example, it's kind of withering on the vine against intense competition against Facebook. How do you see that challenger from the perspective of finding early-stage companies?

WEISSMAN: Well, so this is one of the things I think that's different about the environment we're in right now is that the encumbrance, some of whom you mentioned and others are actually much stronger than they've been. Much stronger, meaning, they're more profitable, they have a lot more cash and then most importantly, I think they're now schooled in the art of disruption, which used to be one of the novel things about the startups we invested in. And so I think as an early-stage investor, you look for characteristics of companies where they won't compete with, you know, the Facebook, Apple, Google, Amazon, those are harder to find than ever before. It is one of the reasons why this thing called block chain that's so interesting because it's an inverse in a way, it could be real competitive dynamic that's very different. But in the other end, it's definitely more difficult. We've been telling our investors that this is a dynamic that we've seen that may could affect venture returns in general.

WEISENTHAL: Yes. When you think about these companies, they just do all kind of things, from transportation to retail to funding, they're on entertainment. Is Blockchain and Cryptos, is that really the one area that you don't see them dabbling in at all?

WEISSMAN: Well, I think the thing definitionally, it's very hard for them too because Blockchain as its course and inverse or the way they operate, all those companies are data companies, they collect data and use those data to monetize and create businesses. Blockchain is an open database and so there is no ownership of the data. In fact, by definition, the date is open and anyone can see it. And so if there is a different competitive dynamic, it -- I think it's the idea that companies that make their business around data can compete against a Blockchain at ecosystem where that date is open. There lots of other questions to ask around Blockchain as well, but I think that's the fundamental that has a lot of entrepreneurs and a lot of investors like ourselves excited. There are other areas as well, but that's the one where that competitive dynamic is very, very different.

JULIA CHATTERLEY, BLOOMBERG HOST: Andy, it's increasing challenge then as you kind of alluded to, actually in terms of when you're looking at a prospect for investment here. The opportunity, the nary in terms of those that don't in any way compete with the increasing size and scale of some of the big tech players, and just having capital now as a venture capitalist kind of built in (INAUDIBLE) you have to offer something different.

WEISSMAN: Yes, that's been the big change in my experience in the past 10 or 15 years is the capital is no longer scarce, the tension is the scare asset as my partner Albert likes to say. And so my capital is the same color as your capital. And so as VC, I think you have to differentiate around different things. And so for example, we differentiate around having very small funds, we only have one office in New York and we're very thesis-idea driven, hopefully that's enough, but I think you have to differentiate around different access. Access and capital is probably the least relevant one of any. Now this is great for entrepreneurs, amazing, incredible time to be an entrepreneur and you're looking for capital because the number of resources you have has increased dramatically. So it's definitely a harder time for VCs.

WEISENTHAL: Andy, I'm curious about --

WEISSMAN: Not that I'm asking for your sympathy, but I'm probably --

(LAUGHTER)

WEISENTHAL: None given.

(CROSSTALK)

CHATTERLEY: (INAUDIBLE) your own promotion --

(CROSSTALK)

WEISENTHAL: None give, but I'm curious --

WEISSMAN: I will take it if you give me a little, I will talk it.

(LAUGHTER)

WEISENTHAL: No, that's all right. I'm curious about how your recent --

WEISSMAN: Yes, I didn't think that.

WEISENTHAL: -- political situation these days because one of the other interesting things is that tech, I think for the first time and longtime has sort of supplanted that role that perhaps finance had whereas an industry that was really popular to bash. And you see, you know, pundits and politicians on the left and right talk about antitrust, talking about companies squelching free speech, all kinds of reasons to be politically angry at tech companies. How do you think about that and how it affects, you know, sort of the tech landscape from your perspective?

WEISSMAN: Well, you know, I think it's a really interesting question. In a couple of aspects, one is, i think these tech companies touch more parts of our lives then therefore as they grow and as they become more powerful, they affect people in a way that feels more visceral because they've touched us. How many times have you touched Facebook today? How many times have you touched Google? How many times have I touched Amazon? Quite a few times. Now, does that mean there -- are they anti-competitive? I think that question is much more difficult to answer. But clearly because they touch us in many ways, we feel the competitive situation, I think a little differently and therefore that anger may expressed itself in different ways. I don't know if that anger is actually an expression of bad practices by these companies or something else that's bubbling up in the things that we use every day.

HYMAN: I'm curious though, Andy, if you do see an actual result of this public anger, if you see increased regulation, if you see antitrust action, et etcetera, how do you feel about that as a VC, as someone who deals with smaller startup players, do think the interests of these tech giants that we're talking about and folks who were in your position, do you think they'd diverge?

WEISMANN: Well, I mean, we compete against them and so if you believe on a theoretical level that anything that enables our companies to compete better is a good thing, then I guess, yes. The answer is yes. I think it's a little more complicated because I'm not sure again that these companies are anti-competitive in ways that we historically think they are. So how would we do that? We think one thing that's important is that given that these companies are data companies and given that individuals were giving them our data that maybe individuals have a different right to our data than we ever had before. And maybe we should have different rights to take our data with us to be portable with our data, to understand our data, to have computers access our data. My partner Albert likes to call it, the right to be represented by a BOT or an API. I think that's where -- I think solutions maybe find in -- maybe found the things like that that are actually a little more market-based than splitting a company up.

CHATTERLEY: So you think actually regulation is a long way off, simply because it's tough to achieve.

WEISSMAN: You know, I would've said yes, but I pick up the newspaper every day this week and there seems to be some groundswell for it. The issue I have is I don't know -- can we count on the regulators to regulate these companies in a proper way because they look so different? Is Google a search engine or is it a car company? Is Amazon a bookseller or a provider of cloud services? You know, Facebook, what is it, you know. And so because they are different, what would you do? And therefore the chances that you can make a really -- mistake that's really bad for consumers. It feels like that's higher. So it requires I think a different type of thought. And so one exercise is to think about of us consumers, we could take our data that we give to this services and use them in other places, is that a solution? I don't know, but it's an idea that maybe is a little more practical.

CHATTERLEY: Fascinating. Great to chat to you, Andy. Thank you so much. Andy Weissman and their partner at Union Square Ventures.

[*]

***END OF TRANSCRIPT***

urn:contentItem:5PGK-6F81-DY0W-40BM-00000-00Andy Weissman is interviewed on Bloomberg TV.2017-09-13T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:11:49ZLexisNexisAndy Weissman is interviewed on Bloomberg TV.WalthamFULL TEXT

(This is not a legal transcript. Bloomberg LP cannot guarantee its accuracy.)

ANDY WEISSMAN, PARTNER, UNION SQUARE VENTURE, IS INTERVIEWED ON BLOOMBERG TV

SEPTEMBER 13, 2017

SPEAKERS: ANDY WEISSMAN, PARTNER, UNION SQUARE VENTURE

JULIA CHATTERLEY, BLOOMBERG NEWS

JOE WEISENTHAL, BLOOMBERG NEWS

JULIE HYMAN, BLOOMBERG NEWS

[*] JULIE HYMAN, BLOMBERG HOST: What'd You Miss? Well, Andy Weissman of Union Square Ventures focuses on early stage investments in the internet, services and information technology sectors. And he is today in the Bloomberg Sooner Than You Think conference at Cornell Tech's new campus on Roosevelt Island. He has been talking about New York City as a technology hub. It has sort of been maybe in the shadow of Silicon Valley to some extent, but certainly has pretty robust presence. Andy, thank you for joining us. Now, when you look at New York and Silicon Valley is sort of opposite poles on the opposite coast here, they do have some similarities, certainly in the terms of costs. So do you find now that New York is not just competing with California but competing with other locations around the country to a larger extent?

ANDY WEISSMAN, PARTNER, UNION SQUARE VENTURE: Well, I think part of the question is how you define competition and in this case I think each region can be unique, New York is clearly unique, it's different than Silicon Valley. And so I find the competition between New York and Silicon Valley to be a bit of a nothing burger if you will.

JOE WEISENTHAL, BLOOMBERG HOST: Well, framing it from a geographical perspective, obviously, one of the big stories in the economy right now is the extraordinary dominance and influence of the major players in tech, your Amazons, Facebooks, Alphabets, Apples, I think that's them. And the difficulty that people -- that companies are having in competing with them, we have seen how snap, for example, it's kind of withering on the vine against intense competition against Facebook. How do you see that challenger from the perspective of finding early-stage companies?

WEISSMAN: Well, so this is one of the things I think that's different about the environment we're in right now is that the encumbrance, some of whom you mentioned and others are actually much stronger than they've been. Much stronger, meaning, they're more profitable, they have a lot more cash and then most importantly, I think they're now schooled in the art of disruption, which used to be one of the novel things about the startups we invested in. And so I think as an early-stage investor, you look for characteristics of companies where they won't compete with, you know, the Facebook, Apple, Google, Amazon, those are harder to find than ever before. It is one of the reasons why this thing called block chain that's so interesting because it's an inverse in a way, it could be real competitive dynamic that's very different. But in the other end, it's definitely more difficult. We've been telling our investors that this is a dynamic that we've seen that may could affect venture returns in general.

WEISENTHAL: Yes. When you think about these companies, they just do all kind of things, from transportation to retail to funding, they're on entertainment. Is Blockchain and Cryptos, is that really the one area that you don't see them dabbling in at all?

WEISSMAN: Well, I think the thing definitionally, it's very hard for them too because Blockchain as its course and inverse or the way they operate, all those companies are data companies, they collect data and use those data to monetize and create businesses. Blockchain is an open database and so there is no ownership of the data. In fact, by definition, the date is open and anyone can see it. And so if there is a different competitive dynamic, it -- I think it's the idea that companies that make their business around data can compete against a Blockchain at ecosystem where that date is open. There lots of other questions to ask around Blockchain as well, but I think that's the fundamental that has a lot of entrepreneurs and a lot of investors like ourselves excited. There are other areas as well, but that's the one where that competitive dynamic is very, very different.

JULIA CHATTERLEY, BLOOMBERG HOST: Andy, it's increasing challenge then as you kind of alluded to, actually in terms of when you're looking at a prospect for investment here. The opportunity, the nary in terms of those that don't in any way compete with the increasing size and scale of some of the big tech players, and just having capital now as a venture capitalist kind of built in (INAUDIBLE) you have to offer something different.

WEISSMAN: Yes, that's been the big change in my experience in the past 10 or 15 years is the capital is no longer scarce, the tension is the scare asset as my partner Albert likes to say. And so my capital is the same color as your capital. And so as VC, I think you have to differentiate around different things. And so for example, we differentiate around having very small funds, we only have one office in New York and we're very thesis-idea driven, hopefully that's enough, but I think you have to differentiate around different access. Access and capital is probably the least relevant one of any. Now this is great for entrepreneurs, amazing, incredible time to be an entrepreneur and you're looking for capital because the number of resources you have has increased dramatically. So it's definitely a harder time for VCs.

WEISENTHAL: Andy, I'm curious about --

WEISSMAN: Not that I'm asking for your sympathy, but I'm probably --

(LAUGHTER)

WEISENTHAL: None given.

(CROSSTALK)

CHATTERLEY: (INAUDIBLE) your own promotion --

(CROSSTALK)

WEISENTHAL: None give, but I'm curious --

WEISSMAN: I will take it if you give me a little, I will talk it.

(LAUGHTER)

WEISENTHAL: No, that's all right. I'm curious about how your recent --

WEISSMAN: Yes, I didn't think that.

WEISENTHAL: -- political situation these days because one of the other interesting things is that tech, I think for the first time and longtime has sort of supplanted that role that perhaps finance had whereas an industry that was really popular to bash. And you see, you know, pundits and politicians on the left and right talk about antitrust, talking about companies squelching free speech, all kinds of reasons to be politically angry at tech companies. How do you think about that and how it affects, you know, sort of the tech landscape from your perspective?

WEISSMAN: Well, you know, I think it's a really interesting question. In a couple of aspects, one is, i think these tech companies touch more parts of our lives then therefore as they grow and as they become more powerful, they affect people in a way that feels more visceral because they've touched us. How many times have you touched Facebook today? How many times have you touched Google? How many times have I touched Amazon? Quite a few times. Now, does that mean there -- are they anti-competitive? I think that question is much more difficult to answer. But clearly because they touch us in many ways, we feel the competitive situation, I think a little differently and therefore that anger may expressed itself in different ways. I don't know if that anger is actually an expression of bad practices by these companies or something else that's bubbling up in the things that we use every day.

HYMAN: I'm curious though, Andy, if you do see an actual result of this public anger, if you see increased regulation, if you see antitrust action, et etcetera, how do you feel about that as a VC, as someone who deals with smaller startup players, do think the interests of these tech giants that we're talking about and folks who were in your position, do you think they'd diverge?

WEISMANN: Well, I mean, we compete against them and so if you believe on a theoretical level that anything that enables our companies to compete better is a good thing, then I guess, yes. The answer is yes. I think it's a little more complicated because I'm not sure again that these companies are anti-competitive in ways that we historically think they are. So how would we do that? We think one thing that's important is that given that these companies are data companies and given that individuals were giving them our data that maybe individuals have a different right to our data than we ever had before. And maybe we should have different rights to take our data with us to be portable with our data, to understand our data, to have computers access our data. My partner Albert likes to call it, the right to be represented by a BOT or an API. I think that's where -- I think solutions maybe find in -- maybe found the things like that that are actually a little more market-based than splitting a company up.

CHATTERLEY: So you think actually regulation is a long way off, simply because it's tough to achieve.

WEISSMAN: You know, I would've said yes, but I pick up the newspaper every day this week and there seems to be some groundswell for it. The issue I have is I don't know -- can we count on the regulators to regulate these companies in a proper way because they look so different? Is Google a search engine or is it a car company? Is Amazon a bookseller or a provider of cloud services? You know, Facebook, what is it, you know. And so because they are different, what would you do? And therefore the chances that you can make a really -- mistake that's really bad for consumers. It feels like that's higher. So it requires I think a different type of thought. And so one exercise is to think about of us consumers, we could take our data that we give to this services and use them in other places, is that a solution? I don't know, but it's an idea that maybe is a little more practical.

CHATTERLEY: Fascinating. Great to chat to you, Andy. Thank you so much. Andy Weissman and their partner at Union Square Ventures.

[*]

***END OF TRANSCRIPT***

The issue I have is I don't know -- can we count on the regulators to regulate these companies in a proper way because they look so different? Is Google a search engine or is it a car company? Is Amazon a bookseller or a provider of cloud services? You know, Facebook, what is it, you know. And so because they are different, what would you do? And therefore the chances that you can make a really -- mistake that's really bad for consumers. It feels like that's higher. So it requires I think a different type of thought. And so one exercise is to think about of us consumers, we could take our data that we give to this services and use them in other places, is that a solution? I don't know, but it's an idea that maybe is a little more practical.

CHATTERLEY: Fascinating. Great to chat to you, Andy. Thank you so much. Andy Weissman and their partner at Union Square Ventures.

[*]

***END OF TRANSCRIPT***

urn:contentItem:5PGK-6F81-DY0W-40BK-00000-00Andy Weissman is interviewed on Bloomberg TV.2017-09-13T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:11:49ZLexisNexisAndy Weissman is interviewed on Bloomberg TV.LanhamFULL TEXT

(This is not a legal transcript. Bloomberg LP cannot guarantee its accuracy.)

ANDY WEISSMAN, PARTNER, UNION SQUARE VENTURE, IS INTERVIEWED ON BLOOMBERG TV

SEPTEMBER 13, 2017

SPEAKERS: ANDY WEISSMAN, PARTNER, UNION SQUARE VENTURE

JULIA CHATTERLEY, BLOOMBERG NEWS

JOE WEISENTHAL, BLOOMBERG NEWS

JULIE HYMAN, BLOOMBERG NEWS

[*] JULIE HYMAN, BLOMBERG HOST: What'd You Miss? Well, Andy Weissman of Union Square Ventures focuses on early stage investments in the internet, services and information technology sectors. And he is today in the Bloomberg Sooner Than You Think conference at Cornell Tech's new campus on Roosevelt Island. He has been talking about New York City as a technology hub. It has sort of been maybe in the shadow of Silicon Valley to some extent, but certainly has pretty robust presence. Andy, thank you for joining us. Now, when you look at New York and Silicon Valley is sort of opposite poles on the opposite coast here, they do have some similarities, certainly in the terms of costs. So do you find now that New York is not just competing with California but competing with other locations around the country to a larger extent?

ANDY WEISSMAN, PARTNER, UNION SQUARE VENTURE: Well, I think part of the question is how you define competition and in this case I think each region can be unique, New York is clearly unique, it's different than Silicon Valley. And so I find the competition between New York and Silicon Valley to be a bit of a nothing burger if you will.

JOE WEISENTHAL, BLOOMBERG HOST: Well, framing it from a geographical perspective, obviously, one of the big stories in the economy right now is the extraordinary dominance and influence of the major players in tech, your Amazons, Facebooks, Alphabets, Apples, I think that's them. And the difficulty that people -- that companies are having in competing with them, we have seen how snap, for example, it's kind of withering on the vine against intense competition against Facebook. How do you see that challenger from the perspective of finding early-stage companies?

WEISSMAN: Well, so this is one of the things I think that's different about the environment we're in right now is that the encumbrance, some of whom you mentioned and others are actually much stronger than they've been. Much stronger, meaning, they're more profitable, they have a lot more cash and then most importantly, I think they're now schooled in the art of disruption, which used to be one of the novel things about the startups we invested in. And so I think as an early-stage investor, you look for characteristics of companies where they won't compete with, you know, the Facebook, Apple, Google, Amazon, those are harder to find than ever before. It is one of the reasons why this thing called block chain that's so interesting because it's an inverse in a way, it could be real competitive dynamic that's very different. But in the other end, it's definitely more difficult. We've been telling our investors that this is a dynamic that we've seen that may could affect venture returns in general.

WEISENTHAL: Yes. When you think about these companies, they just do all kind of things, from transportation to retail to funding, they're on entertainment. Is Blockchain and Cryptos, is that really the one area that you don't see them dabbling in at all?

WEISSMAN: Well, I think the thing definitionally, it's very hard for them too because Blockchain as its course and inverse or the way they operate, all those companies are data companies, they collect data and use those data to monetize and create businesses. Blockchain is an open database and so there is no ownership of the data. In fact, by definition, the date is open and anyone can see it. And so if there is a different competitive dynamic, it -- I think it's the idea that companies that make their business around data can compete against a Blockchain at ecosystem where that date is open. There lots of other questions to ask around Blockchain as well, but I think that's the fundamental that has a lot of entrepreneurs and a lot of investors like ourselves excited. There are other areas as well, but that's the one where that competitive dynamic is very, very different.

JULIA CHATTERLEY, BLOOMBERG HOST: Andy, it's increasing challenge then as you kind of alluded to, actually in terms of when you're looking at a prospect for investment here. The opportunity, the nary in terms of those that don't in any way compete with the increasing size and scale of some of the big tech players, and just having capital now as a venture capitalist kind of built in (INAUDIBLE) you have to offer something different.

WEISSMAN: Yes, that's been the big change in my experience in the past 10 or 15 years is the capital is no longer scarce, the tension is the scare asset as my partner Albert likes to say. And so my capital is the same color as your capital. And so as VC, I think you have to differentiate around different things. And so for example, we differentiate around having very small funds, we only have one office in New York and we're very thesis-idea driven, hopefully that's enough, but I think you have to differentiate around different access. Access and capital is probably the least relevant one of any. Now this is great for entrepreneurs, amazing, incredible time to be an entrepreneur and you're looking for capital because the number of resources you have has increased dramatically. So it's definitely a harder time for VCs.

WEISENTHAL: Andy, I'm curious about --

WEISSMAN: Not that I'm asking for your sympathy, but I'm probably --

(LAUGHTER)

WEISENTHAL: None given.

(CROSSTALK)

CHATTERLEY: (INAUDIBLE) your own promotion --

(CROSSTALK)

WEISENTHAL: None give, but I'm curious --

WEISSMAN: I will take it if you give me a little, I will talk it.

(LAUGHTER)

WEISENTHAL: No, that's all right. I'm curious about how your recent --

WEISSMAN: Yes, I didn't think that.

WEISENTHAL: -- political situation these days because one of the other interesting things is that tech, I think for the first time and longtime has sort of supplanted that role that perhaps finance had whereas an industry that was really popular to bash. And you see, you know, pundits and politicians on the left and right talk about antitrust, talking about companies squelching free speech, all kinds of reasons to be politically angry at tech companies. How do you think about that and how it affects, you know, sort of the tech landscape from your perspective?

WEISSMAN: Well, you know, I think it's a really interesting question. In a couple of aspects, one is, i think these tech companies touch more parts of our lives then therefore as they grow and as they become more powerful, they affect people in a way that feels more visceral because they've touched us. How many times have you touched Facebook today? How many times have you touched Google? How many times have I touched Amazon? Quite a few times. Now, does that mean there -- are they anti-competitive? I think that question is much more difficult to answer. But clearly because they touch us in many ways, we feel the competitive situation, I think a little differently and therefore that anger may expressed itself in different ways. I don't know if that anger is actually an expression of bad practices by these companies or something else that's bubbling up in the things that we use every day.

HYMAN: I'm curious though, Andy, if you do see an actual result of this public anger, if you see increased regulation, if you see antitrust action, et etcetera, how do you feel about that as a VC, as someone who deals with smaller startup players, do think the interests of these tech giants that we're talking about and folks who were in your position, do you think they'd diverge?

WEISMANN: Well, I mean, we compete against them and so if you believe on a theoretical level that anything that enables our companies to compete better is a good thing, then I guess, yes. The answer is yes. I think it's a little more complicated because I'm not sure again that these companies are anti-competitive in ways that we historically think they are. So how would we do that? We think one thing that's important is that given that these companies are data companies and given that individuals were giving them our data that maybe individuals have a different right to our data than we ever had before. And maybe we should have different rights to take our data with us to be portable with our data, to understand our data, to have computers access our data. My partner Albert likes to call it, the right to be represented by a BOT or an API. I think that's where -- I think solutions maybe find in -- maybe found the things like that that are actually a little more market-based than splitting a company up.

CHATTERLEY: So you think actually regulation is a long way off, simply because it's tough to achieve.

WEISSMAN: You know, I would've said yes, but I pick up the newspaper every day this week and there seems to be some groundswell for it. The issue I have is I don't know -- can we count on the regulators to regulate these companies in a proper way because they look so different? Is Google a search engine or is it a car company? Is Amazon a bookseller or a provider of cloud services? You know, Facebook, what is it, you know. And so because they are different, what would you do? And therefore the chances that you can make a really -- mistake that's really bad for consumers. It feels like that's higher. So it requires I think a different type of thought. And so one exercise is to think about of us consumers, we could take our data that we give to this services and use them in other places, is that a solution? I don't know, but it's an idea that maybe is a little more practical.

CHATTERLEY: Fascinating. Great to chat to you, Andy. Thank you so much. Andy Weissman and their partner at Union Square Ventures.

[*]

***END OF TRANSCRIPT***

CHATTERLEY: Fascinating. Great to chat to you, Andy. Thank you so much. Andy Weissman and their partner at Union Square Ventures.

Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:5TP4-7P41-JCMN-Y32F-00000-00An early test of the GDPR: taking on data brokers2018-11-09T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:11:50ZLexisNexisAn early test of the GDPR: taking on data brokersChris Ip

Nov 08, 2018( Engadget HD: http://www.engadget.com/ Delivered by Newstex) Major data brokers Acxiom and Oracle are among seven companies accused of violating GDPR laws on personal information privacy. Advocates hope the complaints will shed light on the opaque ways that personal data is traded through third parties online both in the EU and the US.The General Data Protection Regulation is a sweeping personal data privacy law[1] that came into force in late May in the EU. For the rest of the world, it's viewed as a bellwether for whether Big Tech can be held in check when immense data leaks seem to happen with painful regularity[2].Formal complaints to European regulators under the GDPR by UK non-profit Privacy International were also filed[3] against ad-tech companies Criteo, Quantcast and Tapad as well as credit agencies Equifax (the subject of a massive breach just last year) and Experian."Our complaints target companies that, despite exploiting the data of millions of people, are not household names and therefore rarely have their practices challenged," said Ailidh Callander, legal officer at Privacy International, in an email to Engadget.

"These companies' business models are premised on data exploitation."Data brokers aggregate personal information from other sources -- for instance, websites you've visited or credit card records -- to create a complex profile on who they think you are[4]. That profile may include political leanings and income, and subsequently get sold to brands or social networks. Acxiom claims[5] to have data on about 700 million people globally. Consumers often don't hand data directly to these companies via their own websites -- the way one would with, say, Facebook -- which allows the data trading to operate in relative obscurity.This alleged lack of consent is precisely what Privacy International is targeting. The non-profit also claims that these companies lack "legitimate interest" (in legal terms) for processing the personal data, which may infer political, ethnic and religious affiliations. The companies fail to comply, according to Privacy International, with the principles of "transparency, fairness, purpose limitation, data minimisation, accuracy and confidentiality and integrity" -- in other words, nearly all of the new privacy law's core foundations[6]."The law has changed and these companies need to as well," said Callander. "There is a gap between how [the] GDPR conceptualises data privacy and [how] these companies do and the onus is on them (if necessary, pushed by regulators) to close it."In public statements, Experian has said[7]: "We have worked hard to ensure that we are compliant with GDPR and we continue to believe that our services meet its requirements." Criteo has stated[8]: "We have complete confidence in our privacy practices."Companies are still feeling out just how the law is going to be enforced, which is why test cases like this bear watching. Facebook and Google are among the other companies who have faced complaints[9] so far. A spokesman from the Data Protection Commission in Ireland, where many American tech firms keep European headquarters, said the regulators have already received 2,500 breach notifications and 1,200 complaints related to the GDPR since May. This article originally appeared on Engadget at https://www.engadget.com/2018/11/08/gdpr-data-brokers-complaints/?ncid=txtlnkusaolp00000603 [ 1]:   https://www.engadget.com/2018/09/04/who-controls-your-data/ [ 2]:   https://www.engadget.com/2018/10/24/cathay-pacific-airline-data-breach/ [ 3]:   https://privacyinternational.org/advocacy-briefing/2426/our-complaints-against-acxiom-criteo-equifax-experian-oracle-quantcast-tapad [ 4]:   https://www.engadget.com/2018/09/05/my-digital-shadow-acxiom-corporation/ [ 5]:   https://s22.q4cdn.com/928934522/files/doc_financials/annual_reports/Annual-Report-2017-(Web-ready).pdf [ 6]:   https://ico.org.uk/for-organisations/guide-to-the-general-data-protection-regulation-gdpr/principles/ [ 7]:   https://www.ft.com/content/afef327a-e291-11e8-8e70-5e22a430c1ad [ 8]:   http://fortune.com/2018/11/08/privacy-international-oracle-acxiom/ [ 9]:   https://www.engadget.com/2018/09/13/ad-blocking-browser-brave-google-eu-privacy-law-GDPR-data/

urn:contentItem:5XHX-R4X1-DXP9-93VN-00000-00‘An economic boom the likes of which we have never seen before’2019-11-18T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:11:50ZLexisNexis‘An economic boom the likes of which we have never seen before’Rana Foroohar

That’s a quote from Donald Trump, of course. Apparently, we are in the midst of it. As I have pointed out before, one of the most diabolical... That’s a quote from Donald Trump, of course. Apparently, we are in the midst of it. As I have pointed out before , one of the most diabolically effective traits...

That’s a quote from Donald Trump, of course. Apparently, we are in the midst of it. As I have pointed out before, one of the most diabolical... That’s a quote from Donald Trump, of course. Apparently, we are in the midst of it. As I have pointed out before , one of the most diabolically effective traits...

That’s a quote from Donald Trump, of course. Apparently, we are in the midst of it. As I have pointed out before, one of the most diabolical...

That’s a quote from Donald Trump, of course. Apparently, we are in the midst of it. As I have pointed out before, one of the most diabolically effective traits of our president is his ability to embed a single truth in a welter of lies.

His remarks last week at the Economic Club of New York were case in point. I wasn’t there, but I saw from the transcript that his take on his own economic record got a lot more applause than I would have expected. That may be because the stock market has remained, against many predictions (including my own) at record highs, and the ECNY crowd is full of investors.

But the president twisted a few things in regards to the reasons for that boom, and the ramifications of it. The Fed, as usual, got the sharp end of the stick for its “near record number of rate increase and quantitative tightening.” In fact, I think that one key reason the markets are where they are at the moment is that the Fed has now moved on to openly monetising the US deficit, something that will probably result in currency depreciation (I think my own short term predictions will fare better there).

Already people such as Stan Druckenmiller and   Jamie Dimon are warning about the longer-term impact of America’s debt driven economy. But I worry about the short-term impact — if the markets stay up through 2020, that means we may get Trump 2.

The Fed, meanwhile, is looking hopelessly politicised, albeit not in the way you might think. Central bankers aren’t doing Trump’s bidding. But once the saccharine impact of the Trump tax cuts wore off, it became clear that unless the Fed started expanding its balance sheet again, the whole financialised card game that is the US economy at the moment would collapse. No matter what the long-term cost — the US dollar losing ground as a reserve currency, America looking like Venezuela — they feel morally bound to not let things fall apart on their watch. As Liaquat Ahmed explained in his book, “Lords of Finance,” it has always been thus.

But back to Trump’s speech: another truthful-seeming lie worth calling out is the president’s assertion that “blue-collar jobs are leading the way in the boom”, including mining, energy, manufacturing and construction positions.

The first point is, in fact, true. Gigs at $15 an hour are the fastest growing job categories in the US. But the jobs are in retail and low end services, not mines or factories.

That matters bigly. The program on the Law and Regulation of Financial Institutions and Markets at Cornell has come up with a new metric for gauging that economic transition to low end service jobs — the Cornell-CPA US Private Sector Job Quality Index, which launched last week, found that at the beginning of the 1990s, a little more than half of all private sector jobs studied were below the median weekly wage. Today, it’s 63 per cent. So, while we have “record low unemployment”, as the president likes to remind us, it doesn’t matter so much, because the work isn’t high quality enough to generate real Main Street growth.

In short — we’ve got quantity but not quality. Which is true about so many things these days, from the economy, to the president’s own Tweets.

Ed, do you have a favourite truthful lie from the president?

Recommended Reading

Fareed Zakaria’s story of how he won, and then lost, the Zelensky interview and what it tells us about impeachment and Ukraine is worth a read in The Washington Post.

I also did my own Post column this week, for book promo, looking at how Elizabeth Warren v. Big Tech is really a battle between nationalism and neoliberalism.

My colleague Gillian Tett is spot on in her explanation of why bubbles, not yield curves, are now the marker of where we are in the economic cycle.

Finally, I was lucky enough to receive an award for commentary on foreign affairs from the Academy of American Diplomacy last week, and I had the pleasure of lunch with a group of some of the hardest working and most decent people in Washington — career diplomats. They are obviously front and centre at the moment because of our president. But I’ll be checking out their own fascinating and more heartening stories in these podcasts.

Edward Luce responds

Rana, That’s a difficult question as Donald Trump has told quite a few truthful lies. His harassment of Fed chairman Jay Powell is a good example. Were it any other president, or had Trump been doing so in conventional rather than mobster terms (“Who is our greater enemy? Fed chairman Powell, or Chinese president Xi?”), a lot more people would be agreeing with him. US monetary policy has been too tight for too long — and probably remains so.

Another example is his attack on Hunter Biden’s “corruption”. Again, were it not for the fact that Biden’s actions were a) legal and b) barely a molehill to the Trump family’s Mount Everest of self-dealing, we might be agreeing with him. Washington was a swamp of what I call “soft nepotism” long before Trump arrived. But Trump, of course, makes everything dramatically worse.

Churchill once said that the truth is so precious it must be attended by a body of lies. With Trump, the big lie is so vital to him that it must be disguised with the occasional scrap of truth.

Your feedback

We’d love to hear from you. You can email the team on , contact Ed on and Rana on , and follow them on Twitter at @RanaForoohar and   @EdwardGLuce

Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:5W3B-DR81-JCMN-Y2DC-00000-00An end of Google-Facebook advertising duopoly could be a boon for adtech2019-05-12T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:11:49ZLexisNexisAn end of Google-Facebook advertising duopoly could be a boon for adtechJoanne Joynson-Hewlett

May 12, 2019( e27: http://www.e27.sg Delivered by Newstex) A Facebook Founder called for the breakup of Facebook this week. Will it come to pass? Calls to break up the big tech companies[1] may be overdone depending on which side of the regulatory and political aisle you are on.

But a loosening of the grip by Google and Facebook on the global advertising market will prove to be a good thing for a burgeoning ad tech industry. Any time a monopoly or, in this case, duopoly is unchallenged for too long it harms innovation[2]. That's certainly become true of ad tech of late. Google announced earnings at the end of April and, as expected, we saw its advertising businesses increasingly pressured[3] by newcomers like Amazon - sending the Alphabet stock down 15 per cent, its worst day decline in nearly seven years. To be clear, I'm a fan of Google and Facebook. They've done amazing things for global advertising, connecting billions of consumers seamlessly to brands and marketers. But that has sometimes come at the expense of opportunities for smaller ad tech providers and would-be innovators. The first signs of trouble for the duopoly became apparent during the previous earnings season in February, when Amazon reported that it earned more than $10 billion in 2018 income - most of which came from its advertising business. That raised eyebrows. Indeed, Amazon's e-commerce platform, which has a natural ability to gather consumer data, gives it an edge over Facebook. Google is more diversified with its search business and its Android mobile operating system, which powers most of the world's smartphones. But traffic acquisition costs for Google have been very obviously rising as a percentage of revenue. Competition is forcing both Facebook and Google's costs up in the advertising space. With Amazon as the new competitor, we will move into a healthier state of affairs with a little bit more room for smaller ad tech players to steal slices of the giants' pie. I'm a strong believe that ad tech start-ups and innovators have an important role to play in the future of advertising, with a few big challenges on the immediate horizon that they can help solve. One big challenge is around how to reduce ad loads on consumers, by which I mean how advertising evolves to continue delivering margins and profits while reducing the disruption caused to consumers. This tends to happen when ads are not delivered seamlessly in a way that flows with the content experience they are consuming, be it on a browser, TV, tablet, or mobile. For example, rather than interrupting a consumer watching a TV show with a regular advert, a mixed reality experience prompt could be offered that invites them to learn more about a product they just saw on their favourite TV show. It could be Tesla's latest electric car or Samsung's new folding smartphone. The technology already exists for the mixed-reality prompt to be delivered to the consumer's tablet or smartphone, though the content was being watched on their TV. Also Read: 6 Echelon Asia Summit 2019 exclusives the investor community can look forward to[4] Another use case could include allowing a fashion store to send a shopper, who made it to the changing room but not the cashier, a promo through social media inviting them to go back to the store to complete their purchase - with a suitable incentive. This kind of offline-to-online tracking technology already exists, but challenges remain around how to implement it in a way that is not creepy. Ads need to become more relevant and targeted, but there is also a deeper question about the need for advertising to be reinvented altogether. If there is to be a rebirth of the industry - revolution rather than evolution - ad tech players are going to play a key role in how that's conceptualised, achieved, and delivered. With a more competitive advertising industry, the guys at the top (Amazon, Google, and Facebook) will be forced to innovate more quickly and aggressively in terms of what they offer the buy and sell sides. This will mean many more ad tech acquisitions and greater market incentives for breakthrough technology to be built, bought, and sold. I'm optimistic about the end of the Google-Facebook duolopoly in advertising and so should you be - especially if you're one of the little guys. It will prove to be a big boon for ad tech.
