Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:5YYC-S051-JBVK-H0N9-00000-00A new event study method to forecast stock returns: The case of Facebook2020-07-01T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:11:50ZLexisNexisPgs. 317-321

Received: June 7, 2019; Revised: November 1, 2019; Accepted: November 4, 2019

A new event study method to forecast stock returns: The case of FacebookTiffany Hui-Kuang Yu ahkyu@mail.fcu.edu.tw

Tiffany Hui-Kuang Yu is a Professor of Public Finance at Feng Chia University, Taiwan and a Project Investigator of NISA Project Office, Ministry of Education, Taiwan. She served as the Director of Science and Technology Division Taipei Economic and Cultural Office in Houston during 2015-2019. She had her Ph.D. from Texas A&M University, USA. Her research interests include big data analytics, artificial intelligence, and public finance.

Kun-Huang Huarng b⁎khhuarng@ntub.edu.tw

Kun-Huang Huarng is a Vice President, a Distinguished Professor, a Professor of Product Innovation & Entrepreneurship, National Taipei University of Business, Taiwan. His research interests cover structured qualitative analysis, big data analytics, and electronic commerce.

aFeng Chia University, 100 Wenhua Road, Seatwen, Taichung, Taiwan

bNational Taipei University of Business, No. 100, Sec. 1, Fulong Rd., Pingzhen Dist, Taoyuan City 324, Taiwan

ABSTRACT

This study proposes a new event study method to forecast abnormal returns for individual companies in order to overcome the limitations of current related approaches. We consider two criteria to determine whether there are abnormal returns: individual stock performance and relative performance between an individual stock and the market. We first use in-sample data of Facebook's stock prices between 2017/1/1 and 2018/6/30 to build rules and then employ those rules to forecast its out-of-sample data between 2018/7/1 and 2018/12/31. The empirical analysis shows that our new method accurately forecasts 4 out of 5 negative CNN news items for Facebook. The proposed new method contributes to the literature on case study methods by utilizing a new way to define abnormal returns and to forecast events successfully.

FULL TEXT1. Introduction

Event study methods examine certain occurrences that result in abnormal returns (Li & Tallman, 2011) and have been used extensively in the financial and economics literature. However, they typically just confirm if an event has caused an abnormal change in stock prices or excess returns of an affected company. This study thus proposes a new event study approach that advances the analysis to the level of a forecast, which can greatly enhance the resultant value of an event study.

The present literature uses abnormal returns (ARs), calculated based on a stock's expected return, to check if they are caused by any specific event. The mean adjusted returns model utilizes the average of stock returns over an estimation period to represent the expected return, but it does not consider the relative performances of the individual stock and the market. Conversely, the market model uses linear regression to find the parameters for calculating the expected return. However, a single linear regression may not be able to represent complicated stock behaviors (Woodside, 2014), much less current methods that only are able to pinpoint a single event.

This study therefore presents a new event study method that considers two criteria for abnormal returns (and events). First, we take an extremely high (or low) daily stock return as an abnormal return to forecast events. Second, if the daily stock return does not reach the above-mentioned level, then we use relative performance (i.e., ratio between the daily stock return and the daily market return) to identify the abnormal return. Hence, we are determining the thresholds for both criteria.

To achieve better forecasting ability, this study separates the data into in-sample and out-of-sample datasets. The former covers "known" data, allowing us to determine the thresholds and to build rules during the estimation period. We then use those rules to forecast the out-of-sample data, which are "unknown". The new method is able to forecast multiple events during an event period.

Because the new method relies on "known" data to build the rules, the selection of a target company becomes critical. In other words, we need to find one that has enough events to facilitate our analysis. Social media companies offer a good direction, because they recently have been involved in a number of data breach occurrences. Among the various social media companies, we pick Facebook as our study target for a couple of reasons. First, Facebook is one of the largest social media companies listed on NASDAQ, and second its data and relevant events are publicly accessible.

The rest of the paper is organized as follows. Section 2 reviews the applications of current event study methods. Section 3 introduces the current methods, this study's new method, and the data. Section 4 shows how to build rules from an estimation and then to utilize those rules to forecast events in the out-of-sample data. Section 5 discusses the empirical results. Section 6 summarizes this paper and provides some directions for future research.

2. Literature review

The literature has applied event study methods to various domains such as finance-related problems. Khalil, Mansi, Mazboudi, and Zhang (2019) take one such method to examine the effect of an exogenous increase in information asymmetry on bond prices and find that bondholders react negatively to a late filing announcement. Shi, Xu, and Zhang (2018) set up an event study to show that politically connected independent directors destroy firm value based on an exogenous regulatory change. Velásquez, Kanniainen, Mäkinen, and Valli (2018) also use an event study to examine investor intra-day reactions to two types of layoff announcements. Their statistical significant evidence shows that investors have a strongly negative reaction to layoff negotiations within the first 10 min of stock transactions. However, other strong evidence appears in which the first negative reaction reverses in aggregated cumulative abnormal returns during the subsequent hours.

Carow and Kane (2002) and Howe and Jain (2004)Carow and Kane (2002) and Howe and Jain (2004) utilize event study methods to examine the effect of legislation on the wealth of investors, while Henry (2000) and Jackson and Madura (2007)Henry (2000) and Jackson and Madura (2007) look at the effects of regulations and liberalization on stock performance. Cooper, Dimitrov, and Rau (2001) study the effect of a company's change of name on its stock returns. Rapp, Schellong, Schmidt, and Wolff (2011) exploit an event study to investigate the application of value-based management systems in German listed firms and their effect on firms' stock market performance.

Chernin and Lahav (2014) show how certain important events negatively affect food retailers' stock prices and also that a proper response to these events by retailers could prevent their stock from falling. Tischer and Hildebrandt (2014) conduct an event study to analyze the impact of the publication of reputation rankings by the German Manager Magazine on stock prices. As expected, positive and negative announcement effects exist regarding upgraded or downgraded companies, respectively. Fuenzalida, Mongrut, Arteaga, and Erausquin (2013) explore if good corporate governance practices generate positive returns on the Lima Stock Exchange (LSE) via an event study. Their findings show that the announcement of a firm's inclusion in the LSE yields a positive abnormal return on the announcement day. Furthermore, firms with good corporate governance practices outperform firms with bad corporate governance practices.

Current event study methods have also been directed toward international business. Juasrikul, Sahaym, Yim, and Liu (2018) examine value creation from cross-border alliances between emerging economies and developed economies. Using an event study of 1096 cross-border alliances from 1994 to 2013, they show how emerging economies derive long-term value from such alliances. Extending into the role of directors' within-firm characteristics, Chen and Lai (2015) investigate the impact of an interlocking directorate on the market value of international merger and acquisition (M&A) announcements. Via an event study, they highlight the importance of multiple directorships and their influence on investors' assessments of corporate cross-border acquisition strategies. García-Canal and Sánchez-Lorda (2013) analyze how policy hazards may affect stock market reactions to internationalization decisions made by telecommunication companies. They use an event study method to estimate the abnormal returns obtained by firms expanding abroad and then run several multiple linear regression models so as to estimate the effects of policy risk and the mode of entry chosen on these abnormal returns. Via an event study, Kiymaz and Alon (2011) investigate M&A announcements' impact on wealth gains for U.S. firms involved in cross-border acquisitions of Chinese firms over the period from 1999 to 2007. Their empirical findings confirm that U.S. firms experience statistically significant wealth gains on announcement day.

Current event study methods have also spread to other problems. For a case study, Fan, Lo, Yeung, and Cheng (2018) investigate a corporate label change's impacts on a firm's long-term labor productivity and find that such a change negatively affects long-term labor productivity. They further note that reputable and labor-intensive firms suffer more from a corporate label change. Johnson, Kasznik, Nelson (2000), Carow and Heron (2002)Johnson, Kasznik, Nelson (2000), Carow and Heron (2002), and Chen and Siems (2004) examine the effect of terrorism via an event study. Berman, Brooks, Davidson (2000) and Veraros, Kasimati, Dawson (2004)Berman, Brooks, Davidson (2000) and Veraros, Kasimati, Dawson (2004) concentrate on the effect of major sports events. King and Soule (2007) apply event study analysis to test the effects of 342 protest events between 1962 and 1990 on selected companies.

3. Event study methods3.1. Current methods

The event study literature aims to measure the effect of a certain event on the return of stocks. Thus, we first define an event study periods in Fig. 1a. We name the period between t1 and t2 as the estimation period and the period between t3 and t4 as the event period.

Fig. 1a - The time periods in the event study.

There are different ways to measure abnormality, which implies that stock prices are greatly affected by events. The first way is the mean adjusted returns model, where the expected stock return in the event period is equal to the average of the stock returns over the estimation period:
(1)

The second way is the market adjusted returns model, where the expected return of a stock is equal to the market return. Studies consider that an equal-weighted market index is better for conducting an event study (Brown & Warner, 1980).

The third way is a market model, where the ordinary least square calculates the return of period t:

We now calculate the cumulative abnormal return (CAR(t3,t4),i) of company i, the average abnormal return (AARt), and the average cumulative abnormal return (ACAR(t3,t4)) for the whole market respectively as:

The above methods may have various limitations. The mean adjusted returns model uses the average of the stock return over the estimation period to represent the expected return, but this expected return does not consider the relative performances of the stock and the market. The market adjusted returns model takes the market return as the expected return of a stock, and because it only considers the market, it sacrifices the return of an individual stock. The market model employs linear regression to find the parameters for calculating the expected return, but a single linear regression may not be able to represent complicated stock behaviors.

3.2. New method

This study proposes a new method to forecast how the stock price of a company reacts to events. With this new method, Fig. 1b shows that there can be multiple events during the event period. To ascertain that there is an abnormal return for an individual stock due to a certain event, this study proposes two criteria. The first criterion relates to an individual stock's performance, which is its daily stock return (Siddikee, 2018):
(10)
where and represent stock prices at t and t −1, respectively.

Fig. 1b - Multiple events in the event period.

When an individual stock price rises extremely high or drops extremely low, we denote the stock as exhibiting an abnormal return. In other words, the first criterion ensures that the stock price has risen (or fallen) to a significant level. Thus, we need to determine a threshold from the in-sample data for extremely high or low.

We start with the events from the in-sample data. If an event is positive, then its associated becomes a positive threshold candidate, . When there are multiple positive threshold candidates, we choose the minimal one:where = the threshold for a positive event, Π = a minimal function, and m = the total number of positive threshold candidates.

We next need to find the largest that is smaller than , which we name . From the in-sample data, there is no positive event associated with if is smaller than or equal to . If falls between and , then we need another rule to determine the result. Thus, we derive RULE 1a as follows.

RULE 1a (for an individual stock with a positive event)

IF >= THEN there is a positive event

ELSE IF <= THEN there is no event

ELSE IF > > THEN GO TO RULE 2

If an event is conversely negative, then its associated becomes a negative threshold candidate, . When there are multiple negative threshold candidates, we choose the maximal one:where = the threshold for a negative event, Σ = a maximal function, and n = the total number of negative threshold candidates.

We now have to find the smallest that is larger than , named . From the in-sample data, there is no negative event associated with if is larger than . If falls between and , then similarly we need the another rule to determine the result. Thus, we derive RULE 1b as follows.

RULE 1b (for an individual stock with a negative event)

IF <= THEN there is a negative event

ELSE IF >= THEN there is no event

ELSE IF > > THEN GO TO RULE 2

In summation, if there exists an abnormal return, then must be larger (or smaller) than a threshold. If there is a positive event, then is positive and larger than a positive threshold. On the contrary, is negative and smaller than a negative threshold. The threshold is subject to change for different companies.

The second criterion relates to the relative performance of the individual stock against the market. It provides further analysis to determine if any event has occurred. We define the relative performance as follows:
(11)
where
(12)

Here, and = the market index at t and t-1, respectively.

When is negative and smaller than a threshold, , it means that the stock price of the individual company and the market index go in different directions: one is positive and the other is negative, and vice versa. In other words, the returns of the individual stock and the market are considered independent.

When is positive, it means that the stock price of the individual company and the market index move in the same direction: both are positive or negative at the same time. In this case, we need to exclude the cases when the market factor affects the change in the stock prices. Hence, only when is significantly large do we consider that both are independent of each other. Again, we utilize a threshold, , to distinguish the relationship.

RULE 2

IF < OR >= THEN

IF greater than 0 THEN there is a positive event

ELSE there is a negative event

ELSE there is no event

We obtain ~ from the in-sample data. The events are defined by news. We next check to see if there is any abnormal return either 7 days prior to or 7 days after the date that a piece of news was reported by CNN.

3.3. Data

To demonstrate how the new method works, we target to find a company with numerous news events. This study picks Facebook as our study target for a few reasons. It receives a lot of media coverage, including controversies such as user privacy, user addiction, etc. Facebook is also a listed company with publicly available data and is also one of the largest social media companies in the world. Hence, its relevant events are very open to the public.

This study uses the closing prices of Facebook (target company) and closing levels of NASDAQ (market) as the data for analysis. The in-sample data cover between 2017/1/1 and 2018/6/30 (3/4 of all the data), while the out-of-sample data are those between 2018/7/1 and 2018/12/31 (1/4 of all the data).

To validate the analysis, this study defines "event" as news appearing on Cable News Network (CNN). As of September 2018, it has more than 90 million television households as subscribers. We need to judge if the characteristic of the news is either positive, neutral, or negative. Facebook has recently suffered from data breach events, and so we might be able to tell whether the related news is negative to its stock price.

4. Empirical analysis4.1. CNN news

To validate the empirical analysis, this study uses CNN online news (www.cnn.com). The keywords are "Facebook" and "privacy" under the website's Business category. Table 1 lists the news related to Facebook's stock performance. The first column shows the dates of the news, which is important to validate the event period. The second column lists the titles of the news. For example, on July 27, 2018, there was news stating that Facebook stock had its worst day ever.<link><locator anchorIdRef="ref9t0005"/></link>2018/3/19Why nobody can tell Mark Zuckerberg what to do at Facebook2018/7/27Facebook stock had its worst day ever2018/10/31Big Tech's next European nightmare_ A tax on revenues2018/11/19Dow closes down 396 points as Facebook, Apple stocks fall2018/12/15Facebook could face billion dollar fine for data breaches2018/12/19NYT_ Facebook offered big tech firms more user data than previously revealed
Table 1 - Facebook news appearing on CNN online news website.

4.2. Estimation

For estimation we first calculate , , and for all in-sample data. Here, we find only one piece of negative news related to Facebook in the in-sample period on 2018/3/19, as shown in Table 2; its is −6.77%. Hence, we conclude that , because it is smaller than or equal to −6.77%, was caused by an event. In other words, = −6.77%. The next value close to −6.77% is −4.90%, which was on 2018/3/27, but there was no news around March 27. Hence, = −4.90%. We conclude that with a value larger than −4.90% is not associated with any event. Table 2 lists the data, and so we derive RULE 1b as follows.

RULE 1b

IF <= −6.77%, THEN there is a negative event.

ELSE IF >= −4.90%, THEN there is no event.

ELSE IF −4.90% > > −6.77%, THEN GO TO RULE 2

Table 2 - , , and from the in-sample data.

Because there was no positive news for Facebook from CNN, there is no threshold for RULE 1a from the in-sample data.

For RULE 2, of 2018/3/27 (the only negative news in the estimation period) is equal to 167.04% (). Moreover, there are no in-sample data for Hence, we build RULE 2 as follows.

RULE 2

IF >= 167.04% THEN

IF > 0 THEN there is a positive event

ELSE there is a negative event

ELSE there is no event

4.3. Forecasting

Following Table 3, there are 5 pieces of news related to Facebook on 2018/7/26, 2018/10/24, 2018/11/19, 2018/12/19, and 2018/12/21. We calculate , , and for all out-of-sample data. Following the rules obtained from estimation, we first list all out-of-sample data with less than −4.90% in Table 3. When we check against RULE 1b, both Cases 1 and 4 have less than −6.77%. Both match RULE 1b. Hence, we conclude that both correspond to negative events that pair up with CNN news.<link><locator anchorIdRef="ref9t0015"/></link>CaseDate.12018/7/26176.26−18.96%7852.18−1.01%1878.62%22018/10/24146.04−5.41%7108.4−4.43%122.21%32018/11/19131.55−5.72%7028.48−3.03%188.94%42018/12/19133.24−7.25%6636.83−2.17%334.55%52018/12/21124.95−6.33%6332.99−2.99%211.61%
Table 3 - , , and from the out-of-sample data.

Second, Cases 3 and 5 both have 's that fall between −4.90% and −6.77%. Thus, we move further to check against RULE 2; the 's of both these two cases are greater than 167.04%. Both match RULE 2. Hence, we conclude that they match negative events that again correspond to CNN news.

We lastly check Case 2 (whose is −5.41%) on 2018/10/24. We move to RULE 2. Its = 122.21%, or less than 167.04%. We conclude that there is no event associated with that date, but CNN did have negative news on 2018/10/31, which was one week after. We consider this a so-called misfire. Overall, the forecasting correctness rate is 4/5 = 80%.

5. Discussion

The contribution of event study methods is to particularly forecast the rise or fall of stock prices due to certain events. Our event study method uses events (news) during the estimation period and the in-sample data to determine the thresholds and to build the rules based on the thresholds. We then use the rules to forecast the multiple events in the event period.

Rule 1 aims to check if is greater than the positive thresholds or lower than the negative thresholds. For example, the 's of Cases 1 and 4 are lower than the thresholds, meaning both have extremely negative returns. By Rule 1b, we can proceed to claim that both relate to negative events.

Rule 2 picks up possible events when is not extremely high or low. It checks for relative performance. As an example, the 's of cases 3 and 5 are not extremely low, and so we move to Rule 2. Because both 's are higher than the threshold for relative performance and both have negative 's, we can claim that both match negative events.

Our new method is different from current methods in the literature in many perspectives. First, the new method uses daily stock return and relative performance as the criteria. Second, the new method uses in-sample data to obtain the thresholds and to build the rules. Third, the rules obtained from estimation are then used for forecasting. Next, the rules are very company dependent, as we need to calculate , , and for each company. Lastly, the new method can forecast multiple events.

6. Conclusion and future study

It is very interesting and beneficial to know if the stock price of an individual company correlates to any events. This study proposes a new approach to overcome the limitations of current event study methods in the literature by separating the data into groups of in-sample and out-of-sample. In-sample data help build the rules in the estimation period. These rules then allow us to forecast the out-of-sample data in the event period. This study takes Facebook as the study target, because it is a leading company in the social media industry and its related data and news are relatively easy to access. The empirical analysis shows that the new method successfully forecasts the events.

The rules built by the new method are company dependent, and thus each company has to build its own rules. Thresholds can be considered as the abnormal returns. Furthermore, the new method can also forecast multiple events during the forecasting period and is different from current methods. First, it uses daily stock return and relative performance as the criteria. Second, it employs in-sample data to obtain the thresholds and to build the rules. The rules obtained from estimation are very company dependent and can be used for forecasting. In addition, the new method can forecast multiple events.

Future studies should be able to apply the new event study method to other listed companies for further validation. Additional analysis can also be conducted based on companies from different industries in order to examine for any variances when applying the new method.

Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:5RN5-1JD1-DY2S-100M-00000-00A New Gilded Age2018-02-28T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:11:49ZLexisNexisLEADERBOARDPg. 24A New Gilded AgeRich Karlgaard

Technology prophet George Gilder believes Silicon Valley?s innovations benefit only a select few.

Is progress in technology accelerating or decelerating?

It is not accelerating. It's continuing to advance, of course, but I completely agree with Peter Thiel that technology progress is not inevitable.

What do you mean by that?

Recall Margaret Mead's story of mariner tribes that once made their living building streamlined canoes to catch fish in huge volumes. Over time, they just forgot how to make the canoes. When Mead found them, they were sitting on the beaches looking at the oceans with no idea that canoes were the solution to their food shortage.

But in our day, learning is stored forever on billions of devices. It's not going to disappear.

We're actually at risk of this kind of amnesia. We forget the real entrepreneurial sources of creativity and progress: invention, summed up in technological progress. It's not good to have most of the stock market advance [coming from] five companies, which buy back their own stock and buy up the shares of their rivals. I'm talking about Google, Apple, Facebook, Microsoft and Amazon.

How does big tech's success hurt innovation?

Their success does not represent some fundamental change in technology. It reflects, rather, a vast enlargement of government regulations, rules that really favor big companies. It reflects their capability of lobbying and lawyering and litigating and finding a path through the mazes of rules.

Your next book is called Life After Google. Why that title?

I'm convinced the Google paradigm of massive data centers and artificial-intelligence determinism will be transcended in the next era.

Replaced by ... ?

I'll refer you to Gordon Bell's law: Every ten years, the rate of progress predicted by Moore's Law produces a hundredfold rise in computer cost effectiveness. Which then requires a completely new computer architecture.

Your point being that we're now past the ten-year point of Bell's Law and the cloud.

And lo and behold, a new architecture is arising. It will solve the increasing concentration problem of the internet, which is porous security. It will be millions of small data centers around the world, many of them mobile, all using cryptography and a new computer architecture based on blockchains and other inventions.

Why would Google not see this?

Google is trapped by its own illusion. The advances in machine learning that Google trumpets and preens about are really just advances in the speed of processing. When their Go-playing computer can play more Go games in a minute than the whole human race has played through all history, that's not a great advance in intelligence. It's the same intelligence just accelerated to terahertz speeds. And this creates this illusion for Google and others that machine learning can somehow gain consciousness and usurp humans.

Artificial intelligence evokes both excitement and fear. Elon Musk, for one, is fearful.

Musk is a tremendous entrepreneur and a quite stale thinker. When he starts pretending that he's an ethical visionary, that human life is just a simulation in a smarter species' game ...

A rather demoralizing view of humanity.

It's really nuts. It's clinically crazy. Silicon Valley should stop trying to make human beings obsolete and figure out how to make them more productive again.

GEORGE GILDER SPOKE WITH RICH KARLGAARD, OUR EDITOR-AT-LARGE AND GLOBAL FUTURIST. THIS INTERVIEW HAS BEEN EDITED AND CONDENSED. FOR THE EXTENDED CONVERSATION, VISIT FORBES.COM/SITES/RICHKARLGAARD.

urn:contentItem:5XTJ-FG11-DXY4-X0G6-00000-00A New Outlook on Antitrust Is Taking Shape2019-12-23T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:11:49ZLexisNexisSection BColumn 0Business/Financial DeskPg. 3A New Outlook on Antitrust Is Taking ShapeBy Steve Lohr

A reporter who has covered the tech industry for more than two decades explains how we may be entering a progressive era of antitrust.

Each week, we review the week's news, offering analysis about the most important developments in the tech industry.

Hello, my name is Steve Lohr. I cover technology and economics for The New York Times, and I'm this week's tour guide through recent tech news.

One of the big stories of the year has been the Big Tech companies becoming targets of major antitrust investigations by the nation's federal enforcement agencies, Congress and states. The concern is not only the companies' market power but also how they handle personal data, spread disinformation and amplify partisan divisions.

To someone who has covered technology and antitrust for The Times for more than two decades, this period seems different than anything I've seen before. To me, it raises a question: Are we entering a new, progressive era in antitrust?

The answer to that question matters a lot. The official scrutiny of the big tech companies -- Facebook, Google, Amazon and Apple -- is just getting underway. Whether it results in meaningful curbs on the companies will depend in good part on the persistence of the investigators.

Investigations have a way of finding things. And the institutional commitment to antitrust, or lack of it, will be shaped by economics, ideas, politics and public opinion.

There are intriguing parallels with the progressive era of the late 19th and early 20th century: growing gaps in wealth, concentration of markets and a perceived threat to democracy.

Then, the technology engine was the industrial revolution. Today, it is the digital revolution. Then, the targets of enforcement were the industrial trusts, led by Standard Oil. Today, it is the digital behemoths. Then, the policy response was new antitrust laws -- the Sherman Act of 1890 and the Clayton Act of 1914 -- and aggressive enforcement. Today, the policy response remains to be seen.

While reporting recent stories and a few interviews last week, I've been struck by two things: the very different climate now compared with the one surrounding the antitrust case against Microsoft in the 1990s, and the extent of the bipartisan support for pursuing the big tech companies.

The Microsoft investigation and trial, which I covered, was fairly narrowly focused. It was about market dominance and the software giant's tactics to stifle innovation.

The second half of the 1990s, when the Justice Department and a group of states investigated and then filed a major antitrust suit against Microsoft, were banner years economically. It was not only a period of strong overall growth but a time when productivity rose. For a few years, income gaps narrowed.

Microsoft was a purely economic case. ''But now we're seeing an evolution in antitrust, to take in greater social and political concerns, as well as economics,'' said Maurice Stucke, a former Justice Department antitrust official and a professor at the University of Tennessee College of Law. ''Antitrust is starting to capture the public imagination in a way that Microsoft never did.''

Current antitrust thinking is expanding to take in matters like the control of data and privacy. Since the 1980s, a central focus of antitrust has been a dominant company's power to increase prices. But there is a lively debate now about so-called nonprice components of competition. A loss of privacy to a data-harvesting giant like Facebook or Google, for example, can be cast as reducing the quality of the service and thus as a signal of monopoly power.

''Nothing's free,'' Makan Delrahim, head of the Justice Department's antitrust division, said at the Times's DealBook conference last month. ''If consumers think they're getting any service for free, they're being misled.''

Data, Mr. Delrahim explained, is an asset for internet companies, and gathering and analyzing large amounts of personal data is not necessarily a problem. But digital data, he added, ''can give you market power. And its abuse would be a violation of antitrust law.''

In the last couple of weeks, Representative Doug Collins, Republican of Georgia, who is the ranking minority member of the House Judiciary Committee, has been a fixture on cable TV news as a hyperventilating, partisan opponent of impeachment. But in an interview last month for an article on a Judiciary subcommittee's antitrust investigation of the big tech companies, Mr. Collins was a voice of bipartisan reason.

Mr. Collins is less critical of the tech giants than the Democrat leading the inquiry, Representative David Cicilline of Rhode Island. And he dismisses the calls to break up the companies from the Democratic presidential candidates Elizabeth Warren and Bernie Sanders.

But Mr. Collins supports the House investigation. And he thinks that consumers should be given greater control over how the tech giants use their data and that the companies should be prevented from buying up nascent competitors. ''Those are genuine concerns of mine,'' he said.

Barry Lynn, executive director of the Open Markets Institute, a research and advocacy group, points to the states' investigation of Google, joined by 50 attorneys general and led by Ken Paxton, a conservative Republican attorney general in Texas, as a sign of the changing times in antitrust. An investigation of Facebook, led by Letitia James, the attorney general of New York and a Democrat, has nearly as many supporting states.

''The environment is radically different than it was even a year or two ago,'' Mr. Lynn said. ''It's a grass-roots rebellion against concentrated power.''

But whether shifting sentiments will translate to a pendulum swing in antitrust, reminiscent of the progressive era of a century ago, is uncertain at best. Major enforcement actions would be challenged in court. For years, the courts have generally embraced the ''consumer welfare'' standard -- typically, though not always, dependent on higher prices. The courts have also been guided by the assumption that markets are self-correcting.

''I think antitrust should move, but it will really take the alignment of a lot of stars to move this ship,'' said Andrew Gavil, a law professor at Howard University.

Some stories you shouldn't miss

Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:5HG4-JB71-F0NT-H1P4-00000-00A new representative body for Victorian startups has been established, using the state government's $60 million innovation fund to make it the "location of choice for startups worldwide".2015-11-27T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:11:50ZLexisNexisA new representative body for Victorian startups has been established, using the state government's $60 million innovation fund to make it the "location of choice for startups worldwide".StartUpSmartABSTRACT

A new representative body for Victorian startups has been established, using the state government's $60 million innovation fund to make it the "location of choice for startups worldwide".

FULL TEXT

A new representative body for Victorian startups has been established, using the state government's $60 million innovation fund to make it the "location of choice for startups worldwide".

These are the first announced details of the innovation fund since it was included as part of the state government's budget this year, and the money will go towards investing in core infrastructure, facilitating access to further capital for startups, advocating on federal legislation and regulations, startup events and mentoring programs.

New body LaunchVic will represent the needs of the local startup community and aim to "accelerate startups, drive new ideas and create jobs".

State minister for small business, innovation and industry Philip Dalidakis announced the details for the fund at Melbourne co-working space Inspire9 on Friday morning.

He says he has worked closely with graphic design startup 99designs and the wider community on LaunchVic's branding, identity and core function.

"We want Victoria to be the location of choice for startups worldwide, and LaunchVic will make it happen," Dalidakis says.

"The recent moves to Victoria from the leading tech companies show that it's within our grasp."

LaunchVic will be led by Pradeep Philip, a former secretary of the Victorian Department of Health and Human Services, who will be backed by an advisory board of "industry experts".

"We want to work with existing organisations in the startup ecosystem to collaborate and build together a successful startup sector that will help boost jobs, grow private investment and exports and further strengthen Victoria's economy," Philip says.

The establishment of an independent authority to support startups was first announced by the state Labor party as a pre-election promise last year, and was solidified with the $60 million innovation fund in this year's budget in May.

But progress stalled until this latest announcement.

Before this, the state government's focus has been on attracting big tech players to Melbourne and helping other established companies to expand in order to create jobs.

On Wednesday it was announced the government will be assisting homegrown startup success story Appster amplify its presence and add another 100 tech jobs in the process.

The Victorian government has also worked with big international startups, with Zendesk,   GoPro and   Slack all announcing their regional headquarters will be in Melbourne.

According to the government, well over 300 jobs will be created from these moves, but LaunchVic is about helping new startups get off the ground and supporting the local ecosystem as a whole.

"This is about encouraging young companies and ideas to create jobs and industries that will support our state for decades to come," Dalidakis says.

Do you know more on this story or have a tip of your own? Raising capital or launching a startup? Let us know. Follow StartupSmart on   Facebook,   Twitter, and   LinkedIn.

urn:contentItem:5X98-2XX1-JCMN-Y2S0-00000-00A New Small Business Tech Ecosystem is Emerging2019-10-17T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:11:50ZLexisNexisA New Small Business Tech Ecosystem is EmergingPeter Renton

Oct 17, 2019( Social Lending Network: http://www.sociallending.net Delivered by Newstex)   https://www.lendacademy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/10/New-Small-Business-Tech-Ecosystem.png Karen Mills[1] of Harvard introduced us to the term 'small business utopia' when she released her book[2] earlier this year. She gives the example of the coffee shop owner who had all the information she needed to run her business at her fingertips. There would be an intuitive dashboard that not only helps her run her coffee shop but makes financial decisions and takes the pain out of managing business finances.

Some recent conversations and articles I have read have convinced me that we are well on the way to that rosy picture of the future. And it mainly comes down to data. Fintech is getting better at gathering and analyzing data then presenting it in useful ways. Lenders are approving loans more quickly and many now have such a rich history of their own data as well as hundreds of connections to other data sources that a much more complete picture of the financial health of a business is possible. Not only that but many of these lenders are real platforms with deep insight into their small business customers. According to deBanked[3] the five largest online small business lenders in 2018 were (in order) PayPal, OnDeck, Kabbage, Square Capital and Amazon. For three of these companies lending is just a side business, something they offer as part of their broader platform. Many small businesses use PayPal, Square or Amazon as the platform on which they operate their business. So, these big tech companies have insight into the day to day revenue fluctuations of their small business customers.The Accounting Software Companies Lead the WayWho are not on this list (yet) are the accounting software companies like Intuit, Xero, Netsuite and Freshbooks. I would argue that these companies have even better insight into small business than the likes of PayPal, Square or Amazon. They see everything both on the revenue and expense side as well as the cash flow and balance sheet. Not only that, when you have large market share you see the connections between companies and you can notice problems in real time. Intuit launched Quickbooks Capital[4] just a couple of years ago so they really haven't scaled their lending business yet. But this is a company I am keeping a very close eye on. Because Quickbooks has such a large market share of the small business accounting market they have data on most small businesses and are therefore uniquely positioned to not just make accurate credit decisions but to provide real intelligence to the small business owner. I was speaking recently to a former executive at Xero, the New Zealand-based accounting software provider and Quickbooks competitor that is starting to ramp up business in this country. She said that in Australia Xero had insight into 90% of small businesses there. When you have data on the vast majority of the small business population you can make very accurate predictions on things like cash flow. Xero would see 75% more data than the largest Australian banks meaning they were best positioned to provide the all-encompassing financial dashboard for small businesses. Where are the banks? It is true that large banks also have great network effects and therefore vast troves of data. They could also be the financial hub for small business owners but as yet we have seen few moves by banks into creating the kind of financial tools that others are creating. They have regulatory considerations and also have their hands full trying to innovate on their existing products.Embedded Financial Services is the FutureAnother group of companies to watch are those that focus on one particular vertical. They can build out capabilities unique to a particular industry and while they won't have broad data sets they can go very deep within a vertical. Shopify is a good example of this as they become the go to platform for ecommerce companies. They have functionality they call Shopify Manage which is billed as 'the mission control for your business, wherever you go' available on desktop or mobile. They also have Shopify Capital for lending and Shopify Payments. There are many other verticals where one company is building out the ecosystem for the industry. Toast is doing it for restaurants, MindBody is doing it for the wellness sector, Housecall Pro for home service companies. These companies have the potential to embed financial services in their offerings and become the hub of the ecosystem for their vertical. Speaking of embedding financial services Square added something really interesting last year. They launched Square Installments[5] allowing their small business customers to offer financing to their customers. Suddenly any small business can offer financing and it is all embedded in the software they are using to process customer transactions. Any small business can become, in essence, a lender. I have not mentioned Stripe yet. What Square has done for the physical world Stripe has done for the online world, enabling any small business to accept payments online. In doing so they have become the most valuable Silicon Valley startup in history. They have recently announced moves into lending and credit cards so they are a company to watch in this space. We shouldn't count out the Kabbages and OnDecks of the world. They have been leaders in technology innovation for the past decade and are well positioned to create deeper relationships with their customers. Kabbage, for one, has already announced a movement into payments and they have their Kabbage Greenhouse, a custom-built resource for small business owners.We are Just Getting StartedIt an exciting time to be involved in fintech as new ecosystems are being built before our eyes. But we are not there yet. On the journey towards small business utopia we are probably only in the second or possibly the third inning. But all the pieces are being put into place. All the companies mention here offer API connections that enable real time data that can provide deep insights into the health of a business. Over the long term the world's biggest lenders should be those that have access to the most data and can analyze it most intelligently. Banks may end up providing the bulk of the capital here but it is the new tech companies that I am watching most closely. They are the ones most likely to fulfill Mills' vision of small business utopia. The post A New Small Business Tech Ecosystem is Emerging[6] appeared first on Lend Academy[7]. urn:contentItem:5VV9-J931-F03R-N42C-00000-00A new survey shows that Snapchat is still the favorite social platform among Gen Z — but it's not the app teens are using the most (SNAP)2019-04-08T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:11:50ZLexisNexisA new survey shows that Snapchat is still the favorite social platform among Gen Z — but it's not the app teens are using the most (SNAP)Paige Leskin

Apr 08, 2019( The Business Insider: http://www.businessinsider.com/ Delivered by Newstex) The Gender Spectrum Collection Snapchat[1] remains the favorite social platform among teens, a survey from Piper Jaffray[2] shows. The survey reports that while Snapchat was the favorite social platform, Instagram beat out Snapchat in monthly users among Gen Zers. Despite these numbers, Snapchat's number of daily active users is continuing to fall, and has been long-surpassed by Instagram[3]. Even as Snapchat's user base continues to shrink, it's still cited among teens as their favorite platform, according to a new survey of Gen Zers.

Of the 8,000 teens surveyed[4] by investment firm Piper Jaffray, 41% named Snapchat as their favorite social platform. But Snapchat's lead as the favorite social platform is down 5% from Piper Jaffray's previous survey done in Fall 2018. Even though Snapchat is still No. 1 as the favorite, more of the teens surveyed use Instagram (84%) more regularly than Snapchat (81%). Instagram is only a few percentage points behind Snapchat as teens' favorite social platform, and Snapchat's lead continues to shrink with each Piper Jaffray biannual survey. The growth of Instagram among teens mirrors Instagram's dominance over Snapchat overall. While Snapchat's number of daily active users has shrunk down to 186 million[5], Instagram's user base is continuing to grow, and has surpassed 500 million[6]. Instagram has also become the place where teens prefer to engage with brands. Instagram recently bet big in this area by adding in-app shopping[7], a sect that some analysts have said could generate $10 billion in revenue[8] by 2021. Read more:Instagram's big bet on shopping could be worth $10 billion in 2021[9] The survey also asked teens about their favorite influencers on various platforms. On Instagram, these included Kylie Jenner and James Charles, who have 131 million and 15.2 million followers, respectively, and are influential in the beauty world. Piper Jaffray found that 80% of female teens are using online influencers as a starting point to discover new beauty trends, so it's easy to see how Instagram has become such a major part of teens' time spent online. The survey spelled bad news for Instagram's parent company, Facebook, however. The site's popularity among teens is continuing to dwindle, with only 36% of teens reporting that they use Facebook at least once per month, compared with 52% who said they use it monthly back in fall 2016. Twitter and Pinterest were also in the ranks, but way behind Instagram and Snapchat. The report shows that 44% of teens said they use Twitter at least once per month, while only a quarter of those surveyed say they use Pinterest.NOW WATCH: What's going on with Jeff Bezos and Amazon[10]See Also: Snapchat has finally revamped its Android app after years of people complaining that only the iPhone version worked reliably[11]Britain is coming for big tech — here's how Silicon urn:contentItem:5VV9-5K81-DXY7-W0SB-00000-00A new survey shows that Snapchat is still the favorite social platform among Gen Z - but it's not the app teens are using the most (SNAP)2019-04-08T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:11:50ZLexisNexisA new survey shows that Snapchat is still the favorite social platform among Gen Z - but it's not the app teens are using the most (SNAP)pleskin@businessinsider.com (Paige Leskin)

Although Snapchat was listed by 40% of teens as their favorite social platform, Instagram is increasingly more popular.

The Gender Spectrum Collection

Snapchat remains the favorite social platform among teens,   a survey from Piper Jaffray shows.

The survey reports that while Snapchat was the favorite social platform, Instagram beat out Snapchat in monthly users among Gen Zers.

Despite these numbers, Snapchat's number of daily active users is continuing to fall, and has been long-surpassed by Instagram.

Even as Snapchat's user base continues to shrink, it's still cited among teens as their favorite platform, according to a new survey of Gen Zers.

Of the 8,000 teens surveyed by investment firm Piper Jaffray, 41% named Snapchat as their favorite social platform. 

But Snapchat's lead as the favorite social platform is down 5% from Piper Jaffray's previous survey done in Fall 2018. Even though Snapchat is still No. 1 as the favorite, more of the teens surveyed use Instagram (84%) more regularly than Snapchat (81%).

Instagram is only a few percentage points behind Snapchat as teens' favorite social platform, and Snapchat's lead continues to shrink with each Piper Jaffray biannual survey.

The growth of Instagram among teens mirrors Instagram's dominance over Snapchat overall. While Snapchat's number of daily active users has shrunk down to 186 million, Instagram's user base is continuing to grow, and has   surpassed 500 million.

Instagram has also become the place where teens prefer to engage with brands. Instagram recently bet big in this area by adding in-app shopping, a sector that some analysts have said could   generate $10 billion in revenue by 2021.

Read more: Instagram's big bet on shopping could be worth $10 billion in 2021

The survey also asked teens about their favorite influencers on various platforms. On Instagram, these included Kylie Jenner and James Charles, who have 131 million and 15.2 million followers, respectively, and are influential in the beauty world. Piper Jaffray found that 80% of female teens are using online influencers as a starting point to discover new beauty trends, so it's easy to see how Instagram has become such a major part of teens' time spent online. 

The survey spelled bad news for Instagram's parent company, Facebook, however. The site's popularity among teens is continuing to dwindle, with only 36% of teens reporting that they use Facebook at least once per month, compared with 52% who said they use it monthly back in fall 2016. 

Twitter and Pinterest were also in the ranks, but way behind Instagram and Snapchat. The report shows that 44% of teens said they use Twitter at least once per month, while only a quarter of those surveyed say they use Pinterest.

Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:5JH1-65K1-JBPF-92SB-00000-00A New Threat to Diversity on TV2016-04-11T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:11:50ZLexisNexisPg. 14A New Threat to Diversity on TV


ACCESS



FRANK WASHINGTON

CROSSINGS TV

view point

For most Americans, television is in a new "golden age."

We have more diverse choices - and a richer menu of sports, news, education and entertainment available than ever. There's more direct streaming from the likes of HBO and Netflix, more services like Apple TV and Amazon Fire, and more innovative devices from Roku boxes to wall-size smart TVs with cross-platform search.

We are in the midst of a revolution - one that is allowing television and video to serve the multicultural world that is the America we celebrate. And it has birthed new and diverse voices like my network, Crossings TV, which offers hyper-local programming in six different languages in markets throughout the United States, serving communities that are too often shut out or overlooked.

Yet worrisome new federal regulations proposed by Federal Communications Commission chairman Tom Wheeler, with the support of large technology companies such as Google, have thrown a dark cloud over this revolution - one that could deprive many communities of the tailored, in-language program options we have worked so hard to provide.

Big Tech 'Poachers'

Under the FCC's proposed new rules (known commonly as "AllVid" after an earlier industry lobbying effort the Obama administration rejected in 2010), big technology companies such as Google would be given the right to poach the program license deals we negotiate with pay TV providers like DirecTV or Time Warner Cable without being bound to the underlying license terms that help fund our networks and ensure they get enough exposure to thrive.

The FCC chairman says the rule is intended to create competition for set-top box devices. He argues that exempting these companies from the obligation to negotiate for rights will enable them to focus on developing new boxes to repackage your existing programming and place it alongside the more underfunded Internet video in a single "cross-platform" search.

It's an odd argument on behalf of competition - asking the federal government to subsidize the most wealthy companies so that they can bring more search and advertising services into our living rooms and require yet another in-home box.

Leaving aside that the rationale for this giveaway to Big Tech is totally undermined by the fact that smart TVs and other home gateways already provide crossplatform search, there is an even more compelling reason to oppose the AllVid mandate: It will likely bring us less diversity, not more, in television's golden age.

Today, small and niche networks like mine can negotiate for channel placement they think will help them be seen by their target audience and can cross-promote with other networks to gain exposure from potential fans.

Crossings TV has grown because it has been able to create meaningful local programming in partnership with locally based multichannel distributors - builders of infrastructure and creators of jobs who are physically on the ground in the communities we serve.

But the Wheeler "AllVid" rule directly attacks that crucial system and allows tech firms to disregard negotiated terms such as channel placement, digital rights and much else.

At the Box's Mercy

Further, the cross-search function leaves our channels all at the mercy of the new box's often-mysterious algorithms - notorious for burying disfavored and smaller companies in its ash heap. The dedicated viewers who value networks like Crossings TV have no currency with Google, its fellow Silicon Valley technology inhabitants or profit-maximizing cross-platform search algorithms. Certainly many have observed that the Google workforce looks nothing like the diverse communities it purports to serve. For programmers like Crossings, these giant new boxes could mean a one-way ticket to the back of the bus.

While working to create an African-American focused search browser through Blackbirdhome.com, I saw this problem up close when the Google search algorithm consistently buried African-American-generated content on the lowest rung of search results. Extrapolating that experience to a world of television that is subservient to a Google universal search master box promises a continued outlier existence for African-Americans and Asians, as well as other minorities.

AllVid will further strip-mine our value and harm viewers by serving up new banner ads (for which creators will get no compensation), ignoring privacy protections for your personal television viewing habits, and driving up bills with the massive re-engineering needed to accommodate these privileged devices.

The FCC should step back. Promoting competition is a goal we all share, but the government putting a thumb on the scale in favor of technology giants so that they can sell more ads, track our viewing habits and bury diversity programming - all in the name of competition that already exists - hardly seems to be part of the progressive legacy this FCC should leave.

Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:60HM-5J41-DXH2-61XF-00000-00A new warning that coronavirus deaths could skyrocket as the daily average hits all-time highs in three of the nation`s largest states2020-07-30T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:11:50ZLexisNexisTODAY SHOW7:00 AM ESTDR. STEPHEN HAHNNEWSDomestic073001cb.501A new warning that coronavirus deaths could skyrocket as the daily average hits all-time highs in three of the nation`s largest statesHODA KOTB, TOM COSTELLO, SAVANNAH GUTHRIE

The situation this morning in the three most populated states is described as dire. California, Texas and Florida each marking record high average daily deaths this week. In hard-hit L.A. County, some on the frontlines are demanding better staffing and more protection. Now, a medical association that represents nearly two hundred medical schools in the U.S. and Canada is warning that without urgent action, the death toll could skyrocket well into the multiple hundreds of thousands.

HODA KOTB, co-host (07:00:02): Good morning.

(07:00:03): Midsummer Surge: A new warning that coronavirus deaths could skyrocket as the daily average hits all-time highs in three of the nation`s largest states. Doctor Fauci now suggesting Americans may want to cover their mouths and their eyes.

DR. ANTHONY FAUCI (07:00:19): If you have goggles or an eye face-- or an eye shield, you should use it.

HODA KOTB (07:00:22): Plus, a live interview with the head of the FDA on how close we are to a vaccine. (07:00:29): Big Tech Under Fire:

REP. DAVID CICILLINE (07:00:31): Why on earth would they compare your company to a drug dealer?

HODA KOTB (07:00:35): Lawmakers on both sides of the aisle lash out at the CEOs of Amazon, Apple, Facebook and Google.

REP. PRAMILA JAYAPAL (07:00:42): Do you copy your competitors?

MARK ZUCKERBERG (07:00:44): Congresswoman, we`ve certainly adopted features.

HODA KOTB (07:00:48): Just ahead, what Congress could do to keep those companies in check.

(07:00:52): Honoring An Icon: A final farewell for John Lewis, today. His funeral at an historic church in Atlanta. Three former presidents set to attend with President Obama delivering the eulogy. We`re there live.

(07:01:07): Breaking overnight, Tropical Storm Isaias forms in the Caribbean. Warnings just issued for Puerto Rico and the Bahamas. Florida and other parts of the south bracing for potential problems this weekend. Al`s got the very latest on the timing and the track.

(07:01:23): Danger In The Water: Even more shark encounters put police on alert at beaches across the Northeast.

MAN (07:01:30): We`re asking everybody to please use extreme caution around the water.

HODA KOTB (07:01:34): What`s driving the sudden rise in sightings this summer?

(07:01:39): Those stories, plus, Hoop Dreams.Come True! The NBA`s restart now just hours away.

LEBRON JAMES (07:01:45): Everything is-- is different and you have to be able to adjust to it.

HODA KOTB (07:01:49): We`re live from the league`s bubble as teams get set to tip-off, today, Thursday, July 30, 2020.

ANNOUNCER (07:01:59): From NBC News, this is TODAY with Savannah Guthrie and Hoda Kotb, live from Studio 1A in Rockefeller Plaza. HODA KOTB (07:02:10): Hey, everybody. Welcome to TODAY. So happy you`re joining us on this Thursday morning. Savannah, good to see you, too.

SAVANNAH GUTHRIE, co-host (07:02:18): Good to see you, Hoda. And we do have a busy morning. So much happening, including the long-awaited return of the NBA. The first official games, as you said, inside the bubble. They`ll tip- off tonight. We`re going to have more on that just ahead.

HODA KOTB (07:02:29): Oh, lot of people excited for that. Also, it`s going to be a very emotional day in Atlanta. Congressman John Lewis will be laid to rest, a final tribute to the remarkable life of the civil rights icon. We`re going to have a full report on that, Savannah, just ahead from Atlanta.

SAVANNAH GUTHRIE (07:02:45): All right. But let`s begin this morning with the coronavirus. The pandemic has reached new highs in this country. Nearly four and a half million cases and more than one hundred fifty-two thousand deaths now.

HODA KOTB (07:02:56): Meantime, starting this morning, masks will now be mandatory on the House floor and in all House office buildings on Capitol Hill. The move comes after a Texas congressman tested positive.

SAVANNAH GUTHRIE (07:03:10): And back to sports for a moment, Major League Baseball is now updating its policies after the Miami Marlins outbreak. According to a report from ESPN, players will be encouraged not to leave hotels except for games. And every team is now going to travel with a compliance officer who will ensure the league`s safety policies are actually being followed.

HODA KOTB (07:03:29): In a moment, we`re going to speak with a member of the coronavirus task force FDA commissioner, Doctor Stephen Hahn. But first, NBC`s Tom Costello starts us off. Hey, Tom, good morning.

TOM COSTELLO (07:03:40): Hoda, good morning. This headline just crossing, Johnson & Johnson, a drug-- another drug maker, says its vaccine candidate also appears to be effective against COVID-19 in pre-clinical trials. Meanwhile, nearly a thousand people are dying every single day. This morning, the nation`s chief infectious disease officer is suggesting specifically that we need to be looking at the death toll, the effectiveness of masks, and he`s talking about that debunked video that the President pushed and that was pulled from social media this week.

(Begin VT)

TOM COSTELLO (07:04:12): The situation this morning in the three most populated states is described as dire. California, Texas and Florida each marking record high average daily deaths this week. In hard-hit L.A. County, some on the frontlines are demanding better staffing and more protection. Now, a medical association that represents nearly two hundred medical schools in the U.S. and Canada is warning that without urgent action, the death toll could skyrocket well into the multiple hundreds of thousands. Among the group`s proposals, increasing the availability and accessibility of testing, and establishing a nationwide standard for face coverings. The group also recommends national criteria for K-12 school re- openings. Education secretary Betsy DeVos says how schools reopen must be decided at the local level.

BETSY DEVOS (07:05:02): There is not a national superintendent nor should there be. Therefore, there`s not a national plan for reopening. TOM COSTELLO (07:05:10): It comes as a new study is looking at long-term side effects of COVID-19. A survey of more than fifteen hundred so-called Long Haulers reveals dozens of symptoms that persist weeks or even months after patients recover, including fatigue, body aches and difficulty concentrating.

BETH MOORE (Coronavirus Survivor) (07:05:28): I feel like I`m still in this kind of mental fog.

TOM COSTELLO (07:05:31): And as drug companies search for treatment options and work to develop a vaccine, Doctor Anthony Fauci is warning about a widely shared video, even shared by President Trump, in which doctors touted hydroxychloroquine, a drug the FDA has cautioned against using to treat the coronavirus.

DR. ANTHONY FAUCI (07:05:49): The only recourse you have is to be very, very clear in presenting the scientific data that essentially contradicts that.

TOM COSTELLO (07:05:58): Meanwhile, another member of Congress has tested positive, Republican Louie Gohmert of Texas, often seen without a mask. Without basis, he blamed the facial coverings for his diagnosis.

REP. LOUIE GOHMERT (07:06:09): When I have a mask on, I`m-- I`m moving it to make it comfortable. And I can`t help but wonder if that, you know, puts some germs in the mask.

(End VT) TOM COSTELLO (07:06:21): Mister Gohmert says that he does not have any symptoms right now. Meanwhile, speaker of the House Nancy Pelosi has now issued an order everybody in the House, including staff and members of Congress, now must wear a face covering. Hoda, back to you.

HODA KOTB (07:06:33): And, Tom, Doctor Fauci spoke about something else, he also spoke about the importance of not only wearing the mask, but maybe even eye protection, like goggles or a shield.

TOM COSTELLO (07:06:41): Yeah. Yeah, you know, a lot of people have these. I have them with me all the time in case I`m in a specific environment in which maybe I need the eye protection, certainly on a plane or in a-- in an airport. Doctor Fauci addressed the effectiveness of goggles.

DR. ANTHONY FAUCI (ABC News) (07:06:57): Theoretically, you should protect all the mucosal surfaces. So if you have goggles or an eye face-- or an eye shield, you should use it. I mean, it`s not universally recommended, but if you really want to be complete, you should probably use it if you can.

TOM COSTELLO (07:07:14): Yeah, to be clear, he`s not talking about having it at the house or necessarily when you`re out walking the dog but rather when you`re in an environment, same thing with face shields in an environment with a lot of people. It may be a good idea, but really those face shields are best for medical professionals, hospital workers, paramedics and the like. Hoda.

HODA KOTB (07:07:32): All right, Tom Costello for us. Tom, thank you. Savannah.

SAVANNAH GUTHRIE (07:07:36): And that brings us to Doctor Stephen Hahn. He`s the commissioner of the Food and Drug Administration, the FDA, and a member of the government`s coronavirus task force. Commissioner, good morning, sir.

DR. STEPHEN HAHN (FDA Commissioner) (07:07:47): Good morning, Savannah. Thank you for having me on the show today.

SAVANNAH GUTHRIE (07:07:51): You`re welcome. You know, I know the FDA has some developments to share this morning. I do want to do the big picture first. We have a hundred fifty-two thousand deaths in this country. The average daily rate of deaths is now over a thousand, hasn`t been that since early June. And then you had that association of medical colleges releasing a report saying if the nation does not change its course and soon, deaths in the U.S. could be well into the multiple hundreds of thousands. Do you agree with that assessment?

DR. STEPHEN HAHN (07:08:21): Well, this is a serious situation. And my assessment is that we have to take this seriously. This virus is still with us. We`ve seen some evidence that the very common sense public health measures that we can take, wearing a mask, following local guidance with respect to wearing a mask, social distancing, hand hygiene, protecting the vulnerable, we`ve seen early evidence that that works. We must take this seriously and we must do that because we absolutely need to reduce the number of cases in the country, because that is what`s leading to the deaths that we`re seeing. SAVANNAH GUTHRIE (07:08:55): You know, I was going to ask you this later, but, I mean, since you brought it up, and I`ve heard interviews from you, you`ve been preaching that gospel, saying, "Please wear a mask," for many, many weeks now. You know that Congressman Louie Gohmert, who is a mask critic, has contracted COVID-19. And now he`s suggested that maybe it`s the mask that actually caused it. He said, "I can`t help but think if I`d been wearing a mask so much in the last ten days, I wonder if I would have gotten it. Moving the mask around, getting it, sitting just right, I am bound to have put some virus on the mask that I sucked in." Do you think that is a likely scenario? Do masks cause COVID-19?

DR. STEPHEN HAHN (07:09:34): We don`t have any medical evidence that that`s the case. I heard the clip with Representative Gohmert and I`ve heard from family and friends. There`s lots of people who have questions about the masks. What our data show is that people should wear masks, particularly when they can`t socially distance. And they should follow their local ordinances with respect to masks. That`s something that, you`re right, we`ve been talking about for weeks and months, and I think should be continued the message that the American people hear.

SAVANNAH GUTHRIE (07:10:01): Is it frustrating when you have a sitting congressman who has COVID-19 say something like that?

DR. STEPHEN HAHN (07:10:08): Well, I think getting the message out is the most important thing here, Savannah. We just need to be consistent in what we`re saying these common sense measures to the American people. And I will continue to do that to make sure that people understand that we have the power. We have the power as the American people to-- to slow the spread of this virus. We`ve seen this virus spread in the U.S., but we`ve also seen it around the world. So we know it`s with us. We have to take this seriously.

SAVANNAH GUTHRIE (07:10:37): Let`s talk about vaccines. There are reports, actually an FDA official said that there could be a vaccine approved for emergency use in a matter of weeks. Is that correct? How soon?

DR. STEPHEN HAHN (07:10:50): Well, Savannah, I said before, I was a cancer doctor before I became FDA commissioner. And I didn`t have a crystal ball then and I don`t have a crystal ball now. We do have a number, now two, phase three trials that have started. And this is, of course, in record time from identification of the virus to a phase three trial. Now that phase three trial is going to provide us the data to actually determine whether a vaccine is safe and effective. We`ve seen a number, I mean, a huge number of Americans who signed up as potential volunteers for these trials, and that`s great news. And that will help us accelerate the development, will help the developers. But FDA`s role in this is to provide assistance to those developers, but we`re going to call the balls and strikes on this. And one thing I want to tell you and your viewers, Savannah, is that we will not cut corners. We will use our very high standards of safety and effectiveness. We`ll look at those data and we`ll make a determination based upon those high standards. We have terrific scientists and people at FDA and I know and I`m confident that we`ll do that job on behalf of the American people.

SAVANNAH GUTHRIE (07:11:54): I know you don`t have a crystal ball, but real quickly before I leave it, the President said last night there will be a vaccine before the end of the year. He said maybe sooner. I know anything is possible, but would you consider it to be a strong likelihood that we could have a vaccine ready to be distributed by the end of the year?

DR. STEPHEN HAHN (07:12:13): All I can say at this point is it`s possible. Things have been moving very quickly. I know our team is looking at data in real time from these trials, and that should help us expedite this. But the most important message, I think, Savannah, is we`re not going to cut corners on this. We`re going to look at those data and make the right decision for the American people.

SAVANNAH GUTHRIE (07:12:32): Before I let you go, I have to ask you about hydroxychloroquine. It`s in the news once again. The President retweeted a video promoting it. He even said, "I took it for a fourteen-day period, and I`m here. I don`t think you lose anything by doing it." The vice president said yesterday, "Many Americans have had positive experiences with hydroxychloroquine." But the FDA actually revoked emergency authorization for the drug because it wasn`t effective and it wasn`t safe. It was potentially dangerous. So once and for all, should people be taking hydroxychloroquine?

DR. STEPHEN HAHN (07:13:07): So just to be clear, we revoked a EUA, an emergency use authorization, at the request of another government agency BARDA. And this was for drug that was authorized for use in sick hospitalized patients. We had data that when this drug was combined with others, there were some risks associated with that. But the decision that the question you`re asking me is a decision between a doctor and a patient. A doctor and a patient needs to assess the data that`s out there. FDA does not regulate the practice of medicine. And that in the privacy of a doctor/patient relationship is where that decision should be made.

SAVANNAH GUTHRIE (07:13:43): Are you concerned at all about misinformation about this drug in particular?

DR. STEPHEN HAHN (07:13:50): I am-- I am-- what I`m concerned about is that FDA provide all the information about the side effects, the potential side effects as well as the efficacy. As you know, these drugs have been approved for a number of years for other indications by the FDA. We`re know-- we know that they`re safe in those settings. But we want to make sure that the right information is out to providers so that they can make this decision with patients.

SAVANNAH GUTHRIE (07:14:13): Doctor Hahn, yes, you have your hands full and we appreciate your work. Thank you so much. Thanks for your time this morning, too.

DR. STEPHEN HAHN (07:14:22): Thank you, Savannah. Have a great day.

SAVANNAH GUTHRIE (07:14:24): You, too.

(07:14:25): All right. Hoda, seven-fourteen, I`ll send it to you.

HODA KOTB (07:14:27): All right. Thank you. Craig joins the table now. A closely watched hearing on Capitol Hill yesterday, Craig.
