Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:5JRV-MCW1-JB20-G270-00000-00Anixter International Inc at Wells Fargo Industrial and Construction Conference - Final2016-05-10T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:11:50ZLexisNexis051016a5997059.759Anixter International Inc at Wells Fargo Industrial and Construction Conference - Final

Corporate Participants

* Ted Dosch

Anixter International Inc. - EVP Finance & CFO

Presentation

UNIDENTIFIED PARTICIPANT: We have Anixter's CFO, Ted Dosch and Lisa Meers from IR. I guess, Ted, for the benefit of those (inaudible), please give a brief overview of what's the Company is, what you've been to, the products that [you play in]?

TED DOSCH, EVP FINANCE & CFO, ANIXTER INTERNATIONAL INC.: Sure, as of next year, we'll be a 60-year old company that started in the power cable, the wire cable business. The tagline they used back then you sometimes hear around the Anixter [by about a mile, still by the foot], which seems a little simplistic, but it is kind of the hallmark of our business model yet today, in that we aren't just a distributor, it is all about being a value-added distributor.

So today, we've gone from that wire and cable business in the power business, which now represents a little over $2 billion of our revenue. Our largest segment is all about data, in the network in the horizontal LAN -- I'm sorry, in the data center, horizontal LAN network and security that's about $4 billion business for us, that's the only one of our three businesses that's in 50-plus countries around the world. And then the newest part of our business came as a result of the acquisition of Power Solutions from HD Supply. It was the electrical distribution and utility business that they had and the utility portion of that business, which represents about $1.5 billion of revenue is what we call our UPS segment, Utility Power Solutions.

UNIDENTIFIED PARTICIPANT: That's great. And one of the questions I've been asking everybody, are we in a recession, right, it's a big question for industrial, maybe just your high level thoughts of where we are in this cycle, could we be tipping into a recession?

TED DOSCH: Yes, it's a great question and I kind of answer it in two parts. Are we in a recession? No. Are we in a recession for industrials? It kind of feels that way. So first, outside industrials, our NSS base, our Network & Security Solutions business had continued to grow at an organic growth rate of about 4% for I think the last four quarters in a row. We've had positive organic growth there, 10 quarters in a row, that's a business that we feel very good about. Secular drivers as well as our position that will allow us to grow at a rate probably 150 to 200 basis points above market.

Specifically though in EES, Electrical & Electronic Solutions, two major segments of that business are mining and oil and gas. Mining has been down a good 2.5 years, going on three years. Oil and gas, the way we look at it, will be two years in June. June of 2014 is when we really began to feel and see the significant impact and then, it's probably approaching one year since that oil and gas softness translated into broader weakness across the broader industrials.

So based on what we're seeing there, the pullback which to us the area that has the most significant impact is when industrial customers pull back on CapEx spend that's what has the most significant impact on the products that we sell. That's been a factor out there for about a year. Having said that, in Q1 we don't feel that what we've seen changing the market is enough to cause a turn or to necessarily say we hit the bottom, but at least based on the indicators we're seeing including pipeline, number of RFPs, new quotes et cetera that are out there, it feels like the word we used a lot on our call was stabilizing, I'd like to give it another quarter or two (multiple speakers) to really turn the corner but reason for optimism is that we did see much more activity from the pipeline standpoint.

Our backlog at the end of Q1 was up double-digit percentage wise, low-teens from where it was at the end of December and up a similar number from where it was a year ago March. So two indicators that I think there is some light at the end of the tunnel, I'm not sure if that's one quarter or two quarters or when.

UNIDENTIFIED PARTICIPANT: We see Anixter has a unique portfolio right now. You mentioned the term secular drivers. Can you kind of help us understand the secular drivers very unique in the space right now?

TED DOSCH: Again, I really need to take it segment by segment, because it does vary. So in our largest segment, NSS, $4 billion, about 60% of that is really data related, data center spend, horizontal LAN spend, wireless spend et cetera. So the key drivers of that -- the single biggest one is data, whether it's companies and their needs and their data center, whether it's all of us with our cell phones and iPads, et cetera that we want more data, more video, more graphics, by the way we want it faster than we've ever wanted before. So that drives the need for data spend growth in both the data center as well as bandwidth. So it's both storage and transmission.

So with that, we continue to see growth, not as high as it was a few years back, but again probably at 3% type growth in just basic data center spend and that's both in what I would call enterprise spend, companies like Anixter where we have our own data center. It's in multi-tenant data centers, the companies like Equinix and Digital Realty that's still a relatively small part of the industry, it's probably only about 9% or 10% of the industry today; projected to grow to 15% in the next three years or so. So percentage wise, it's growing rapidly. Both of the big guys have done significant acquisitions and so they're getting a bigger percent of footprint. And then what we or the industry sometimes refers to as the hyper data centers, that's the big tech guys, the Google, the Amazon, eBay, Microsoft, et cetera, the growth in cloud, software-as-a-service in general, all of that, their spend is continuing at a very, very large clip, and it's not just US spend and that's where we think we have a competitive advantage because we work with these guys with the same products, the same level of service, the same system and so forth wherever they're building. If they're building like out in California with Apple's new headquarters and we're doing their data center and their headquarter wiring or whether it's three of them that are building data centers in the Nordics right now, or whether it's in Asia or elsewhere.

Let me just comment on wireless. Even though wireless is a very small part of our business today, it's the fastest growing of any product segments within our entire portfolio. It grew at a cliff of almost 50% last year. We'd expect it to grow at a similar cliff this year and again, back to all the handheld wireless devices we have, it's buildings like this and others where the signal is weak in the building, and more and more of these micro-cells, the DAS, distributed antenna systems are being installed to connect to the exterior macro-cell.

Jumping to EES for a moment, despite the softness in the power industrial switches, I would say a more macro damper, if you will, to overall demand, there are areas of that business both that are showing signs of improvement, but also I would [say sort of a secular] driver and more of our product positioning and our services positioning, one of which is what we refer to as ITC, Industrial Communication and Control, because it's a subset of industrial automation and the trend -- and we all know there has been automation in factories for decades, but what's changed in, say, these last three to five years, which is driving the real opportunity for us is as these companies have gone from -- or the technology has gone from proprietary technology to more open architecture, what's happening is all this automation that was on the assembly line or a paint booth or in a stamping press department instead of all that data being collected right there at the work site, now it's being connected to their ERP systems. This data is feeding their ERP systems. One of the quotes I like reading about this phenomena is for the first time CIOs care what happens on the plant floor because out and all that data is feeding their systems.

So we have a business that's grown to over $0.25 billion up until this last year with the softness in industrials was growing at a cliff of about 20% CAGR for the last few years and that's all organic. We haven't done any acquisitions in the space. We certainly -- it's a possibility but it's an area that I think despite the secular headwinds, we're positioned very well for that.

And then the other one that I'll comment on that is not driven by kind of the macro demand that's more driven by our recent acquisition of Power Solutions, one-third of that business was what they refer to as Construction and Industrial C&I, the low-voltage business. This is a very strategic opportunity we felt to blend that business into our legacy Wire & Cable. Our Wire & Cable business, even though it was a couple of billion dollar business, 80% of our revenue was still cable. The business we acquired on the low-voltage side, only 20% of that business was wire and cable. So we picked up lighting and switchgear and transformers and other products, all of which connect to our cable by the way, but it gives us an opportunity to have a broader portfolio, a greater share of wallet with many of these customers.

And then lastly in the utility side, it's a business that the experts would say as an electric institute and other folks say, hey, this business is going to grow, CapEx spend is going to grow 4% to 5% CAGR for the next five years. Well, it hasn't been doing that recently and they point to a whole lot of reasons why but reason to believe that that trend will change I think are what critically point to things like the aging grid, the infrastructure and some would say, well, they've been talking about that for years and CapEx didn't grow. Well, what's changed now is the propensity of FERC and the local state energy regulatory authorities to allow them to recover the CapEx through rate increase, which historically grid spend was considered normal maintenance and you couldn't get incremental rate for it. So the fact that they're starting to grant that is a plus.

Secondly, smart grid, a major part of that UPS segment of ours is automation of smart meters and so forth.

And then thirdly, and this one we think we're uniquely positioned in, there is a tremendous opportunity with security products into utility space. Again, regulatory requirements at all these utilities have to have a plan by the third quarter of next year to harden their substations. In recent years, somebody trying to shoot out a transformer in California and try to bust down the gate and destroy the substation or whatever, it isn't just a function of keeping the grid up and keeping the lights on, but the requirements we think fit right in our wheelhouse as these utilities don't typically have the security expertise and we're meeting with all of the major utilities to help them identify what that game plan or what that kind of turnkey proposal is to provide a security solution for substations.

UNIDENTIFIED PARTICIPANT: These are all great and I think one of the questions is it's hard to find secular growth drivers [to ebb rates] that are offsetting these headwinds. What about competitive dynamics? Do you see people trying to enter this market because of those trends and what can Anixter do to protect sort of their share of mind?

TED DOSCH: It's a great question. No matter how you look at it, all our three segments and in all of our geographies, so very fragmented business. So I think there certainly is room for consolidation and the challenge with that, I think is less on kind of the distribution side and more on the supply side.

There's a lot of, well, I would say most of these key distributors or I'm sorry, key suppliers out there are already heavily distributed. So they aren't necessarily looking to pick up another new distributor that type of thing. But when we think about distribution in general, which most people would think of as having low barriers to entry, again, that's why our focus so extensively is not on price, but it's on the value-add services. The supply chain services, the cable management, the technical expertise that we bring to bear is typically why we aren't the low price guy when it comes to a pure product play and focus on those value-add services.

UNIDENTIFIED PARTICIPANT: And when I think of wired cable, copper comes to mind. Can you walk through how you manage sort of that copper, the volatility, once we see it, obviously commodities are --

TED DOSCH: Copper is certainly a factor and the way it's shaping up right now, it's actually going to be a bigger headwind in Q2 than Q1, because last year, Q1 to Q2 copper went up. This year Q1 to Q2, copper went down so the gap year-over-year is just a little greater this year than last.

I think our guys do a really good job of helping to minimize or mitigate the risk associated with fluctuations in copper. First off, lower copper price is not a hit to our gross margin percentage, but it is dollars, because we have a model like many distributors, our guys are going price it at X percent above the cost of the input. So number one, inflation is our friend, but with a lower copper, it tends to be a pass-through to the customer. But when copper is lower, our revenue is lower and it's one of those days - it's like your pricing, revenue is lower, but expense didn't drop so it puts operating margin pressure.

The way -- we work on an average cost basis. Our sales folks know every day what the average cost of any SKU is in our system. So they have a real-time information to help ensure that they're driving towards their margin goals and if copper is dropping like it is today, we don't want -- while we know we've got higher cost product in the warehouse that hasn't sold through yet, we don't want our salespeople incentivized to go to the market so to speak, to go to the lower price and just us take a hit in pricing.

So I think we have incentive programs with our sales folks to help ensure that they're not just rewarded based on revenue but they are rewarded based on gross margin percentage.

The other key thing I think as a way to help mitigate this risk when it comes to larger projects that tends to be where the biggest risk is, customers coming in and placing a six, seven figure type order for products and they want delivery in 60 days or 90 days or six months. We have a practice at Anixter, we negotiate with our suppliers that when a customer is placing a dated order, again, we don't speculate. So if the customer says I think copper is going up, I want to lock in today's price, we place a back-to-back order with the supplier and lock in today's price as well, so we have no risk associated with the price of that product even if it's going to be delivered in three months, six months or 12 months. Those other times like in a more recent environment where the customer might say I think copper is going down further, and they place the order today and say I want to lock in whatever the price will be on date of delivery and in that case, we do a back-to-back and we lock it in even though we don't know what the price is, that's the risk our supplier takes.

So we're not speculating, we're not trying to make money on the copper market per se, it is about mitigating risk and about letting our guys do what they do best, which is sell the product, sell the value-add, take out the risk associated with those big projects.

UNIDENTIFIED PARTICIPANT: And in line with (inaudible) obviously, the big application with the power solution side, you touched but there is still (inaudible) within couple of areas where you'd like to grow. How do you view the M&A environment? Are you still absorbing Power Solutions and then taking a little breather from now, how should we think about that within the --

TED DOSCH: Yes, it's a great question. The easy answer in the short-term is I'll say we're taking a breather but I don't anticipate us doing any major acquisitions in the next 12 months to 18 months for a couple of reasons. One, we levered up higher than where we typically would like to be as a result of this acquisition. And two, key metrics that we're shooting for in our strategic goals, we want to have leverage in the 2.5 to 3 range. We went up to 3.8 as a result of this acquisition, which is an unreasonable or overly burdensome. We got this already down to 3.7 at the end of Q4, we would expect that get down to 3 by the second half of next year.

The other metric is we look at debt-to-total cap. We're very comfortable on a 45% to 50% range. We went up as high as 58% at the end of Q4. We got it down to 56% at the end of Q1. Again, we think that'll be down below 50% in the back half of next year. So from a cash flow, cash allocation standpoint for this next 12, 15 months, it's about paying down the debt to get us down into those target levels but in the meantime, we need to be focused on integration.

So back to my point, we've not exactly taken a breather, but there's still a lot of heavy lifting to do with the integration.

We're extremely pleased with where we are 18 months into the Tri-Ed acquisition and six months into the Power Solutions acquisition, but there's still a lot more to do in delivering on the $40 million of synergies that we've targeted for these acquisitions. Having said that, if we're sitting here late next year, have our debt where we like it and we don't see the right opportunity in the M&A pipeline, we will be considering what we've done in the past with returning value to shareholders, which has historically been through either share repurchase or special dividends.

UNIDENTIFIED PARTICIPANT: So I'm thinking a year -- 12 months to 18 months from now, what would an acquisition look like, would it be a product sort of holding you're trying to sell, an end market, a region, how should we think of the strategic view on acquisition M&A?

TED DOSCH: It could be one or more of them and so let me frame it this way. First off, we don't feel that, we just literally are finishing our strategic plan that we'll present to our Board of Directors in two weeks. We annually do that in the month of May. We do not feel we have gaps that are as extensive as a fourth leg to the stool, so to speak. We think there is plenty of work to do around these three segments that we have. What I would see though, which would be less than a fourth leg of the stool, is some -- maybe more niche opportunities. I mentioned wireless. Wireless is still a small component of our business. Prior to this Tri-Ed acquisition, we grew our security business to over $1 billion almost exclusively organically. We may not wait that long to do an acquisition in the wireless space, as an example.

Utilities, right now the utility business is only US and Canada. We think there's tremendous opportunity to take those products globally, sourced out into Mexico and beyond and then into Europe. We're not sure yet dynamics around organic versus inorganic but that could be a possibility as well. And in security, securities just continue become core to our business and we may have the opportunity, I'd say outside North America, I don't really think there is any inside North America to help us say accelerate the growth rates, to get the critical mass faster elsewhere around the world in the security space.

UNIDENTIFIED PARTICIPANT: That's great. And you touched on integration, HD Supply, very good operators are going to be on other Power Solutions business, I guess can you walk us through that process of the integration, can you even improve those margins, offset volumes and is there anything that they're bringing to the table to you that maybe (inaudible)?

TED DOSCH: First off, we've been studying them for quite some time. We'd actually been in dialog with HD Supply even before the IPO, partly because when we took our strategic plan to our Board in 2012, we said we have a gap in Wire & Cable, it's called low-voltage products and we really want to expand into utility. It took us three years to fully execute that and in the meantime, we looked at a lot of other companies and quite frankly, even though, as I mentioned before, it's a pretty much fragmented marketplace out there, we didn't find one that we felt we could get at least -- we want to get at least two of our three key objectives within that space and this part of the business gave us two of the three, the low-voltage products and the utility part, the third one we didn't get is ITC. I mentioned we grew that business to $0.25 billion and we were thinking if we could get an acquisition to help us significantly grow that business that would be kind of the icing on the cake.

But as we looked at other companies, one, some weren't interested in being bought, some even though they were substantial in a region, they didn't have a national footprint and we felt we'd end up having to do two or three acquisitions and each acquisition in of itself has a certain amount of risk associated with the integration. So we've got going with the larger footprint like Power Solutions hope to reduce some of that risk.

So again, so it was probably a three-year dialog with them. Ultimately, they determined the time was right for them and it was a pretty competitive process with both strategics and sponsors involved along the way. I would say that, we think, clearly think we have been able to and are able to bring to the table relative to the acquired part of the business, a lot of that has to do with some of the value-add services and technical expertise, et cetera. And it's just from business processes. That was a business that was -- it really wasn't even run as one company. This isn't meant to be a critique of HD Supply, but HD Supply was a bunch of acquisitions sewn up together. It was still being operated as two companies, a low-voltage company with one ERP system and one set of warehouses and one sales force and a utility high-voltage as another. So there is a lot of back office leverage and cost take out that we can do as we get that converted to our systems, but the bigger part is they were very, very decentralized when it came to procurement and inventory management and so forth. So we think there's some opportunities when it comes there.

On the flip side, they do a really, really good job in managing and executing day-to-day serving utilities. Utilities for the most part are high demand, hard-to-keep happy type customer for a whole lot of reasons and they have kept some of these customers for 5, 10, 15, 20 years if you go back to some of the predecessor organizations like Hughes Supply bit of had some of these customer relationships for 20 years or 25 years. The only way they've done that, I'm sure you've got to meet the financial requirements, but they mainly kept that business because of their day-to-day execution and their ability to deliver on service. So they do some things really well that I think we can apply in some of our more complex service offerings.

UNIDENTIFIED PARTICIPANT: And then touching on service offerings, it's a little bit unique versus just buying and selling being the middleman. Maybe elaborating on some of the unique things that Anixter does in terms of value offering?

TED DOSCH: Sure and maybe I'll hit on one real quick in each of the three segments. But in NSS, tech security for example, in many of our security products that we sell into, it's a complete turnkey operation. So take, this will be a real-life example, from a few years back, New York City, we're doing major project partnering with IBM and the Homeland Security Group of New York City in putting video cameras around the city. It was thousands of cameras in thousands of locations where we didn't just ship a whole bunch of cameras and a whole bunch of cable and a whole bunch of connectors in our warehouse to make it a complete turnkey.

First off, we helped them configure just exactly what they need and it wasn't the same camera everywhere. It depends on what the light is here, what -- facing the sun or not, what the requirements are in this location, et cetera. But we basically in our warehouse took thousands of cameras, we opened them up, did a DOA check on, loaded the software from IBM, serial number tagged them, installed them or sub-assemble, if you will, into an enclosure to protect from the weather, put the cable on at the connectors, all that goes into a box labeled 101 for example, so that the installer in the field has a kit to install on pole 101 or whatever.

So significantly reduced the total cost of acquisition, increased the cost of raw parts, but significantly reduced the total costs including labor and de-risked it, so now you don't have lose parts, mismatched assemblies, delays in installation, et cetera.

In the case of EES, we have extensive cable management practices. For example, there is a new manufacturing plant being built. We work with the contractors. We do take offs on all the engineering drawings. So we're not just shipping big reels of cable there to be installed, to be cut and installed et cetera. We'll know for example that (technical difficulty) 10,000 feet of this size of cable, it's 2,500 foot lengths on this day and it's five 100 foot lengths on this day et cetera. We cut the lengths, deliver on site, so it is a just-in-time delivery type operation that again reduces their overall cost, because without that a general contractor trying to manage that will always over order and a typical project would had 10% to 15% material wastage.

So we not only get that cost out of it but we ensured that the right product is available for installation on the right day, et cetera.

And then lastly in UPS, they do a great job as I mentioned with a lot of that day-to-day execution. I'll give you just two quick examples there. One is storm response. So our warehouses in that part of the business, we have people on 24/7 available. So when the storm hit, the trees knock the power lines down, neighborhoods are out of electricity, our guys are headed into the warehouse. So we have SLAs with these utilities that we have to have certain products available within so many hours for a storm response and we get great accolades for the ability to meet those requirements. Again, it's always unpredictable. You don't know where it's going to hit or what the magnitude of it.

The other thing I would say and this is a great opportunity for outsourcing of work from utilities to us. But when there's a major project like in the Northeast, we're just working on completing a three-year project. It was a 500-mile build of transmission cable and so Utility because over the years, they hadn't done many of these projects, they no longer have the capabilities in-house so they completely outsourced the project to us. So what do we do for them, when I say the project, I'm sorry, we [weren't] installing and so forth, but outsourced the inventory management of it, the acquisition of the product and the inventory management.

So we're out there. If you're building 500 miles of transmission cable, you're going out somewhere in the middle and nowhere and we're leasing some land, we're building a laydown yard, we're having two feet of gravel brought in so that product and big equipment can be stored, et cetera. All the product comes in direct shipped from the manufacturer and we are actually managing that yard to service say 50 miles of construction. Three months later when they finished that, we actually moved 100 miles down the road and set up a new laydown yard and then service that project for the next 50 miles or whatever. So it's gone well. It certainly involves obviously, procurement of material and inventory management, but the service that we're providing typically at much, much higher margin than just a markup on material is the ability to manage that entire activity, which includes acquiring the land, building out the laydown yard, everything associated with making that a turnkey service for them.

UNIDENTIFIED PARTICIPANT: I know we're running out of time. Does anybody have a specific question or I'll keep going. You talked about margins of value-added service. Gross profit and gross profit margins have been a challenge for distributors as a whole. (inaudible) to Anixter, how are you protecting those margins, how do you expect to grow the gross profit margin going forward?

TED DOSCH: Yes, it's a great question. One thing not to start with a pat on our own back, but we have been able to maintain our gross margin percentage throughout kind of the cycle. Now, if you look at the absolute numbers as reported, our gross margin down versus a year ago, which is completely a function of selling a high margin business and acquiring two businesses with lower gross margins. But if you take kind of the reformed -- repositioning of the business aside, our gross margins have been pretty flat over the last five or six years, which I attribute to a good job of managing copper and its volatility, managing deflationary pricing pressure. Some of our products that have become more commoditized have much greater pricing pressure on the data side, for example, pretty standard Cat5 cable, four pair of copper data cabling price is down 19% in the last four years.

So we've offset that and then we've also offset the impact of product mix. And what I mean by that is in security, which is growing faster than the data center side of NSS, by its nature tends to have lower margins and I say, well, why is it? The big ticket items in security are electronics: video cameras, DVRs, et cetera. Well, you can go to Best Buy and buy a video camera coming from some of those same manufacturers and you're going to pay a whole heck a lot less than you would have to three years ago. The same thing applies to security cameras. So the ticket price of those are coming down. We're still getting the same margin percentage, but the higher the gross revenue, the average sales price continues to drop.

So my point is as security grows faster than other areas that puts downward pressure on the consolidated margins.

What we've been able to do I think with more value-add services, with some -- I'd say some new software we've installed to help our salespeople to make smarter pricing decisions day in and day out and doing, I would say, just a better job of getting value for the services that we're providing that hasn't significantly grown our gross margin, but it's helped compensate or offset the effects of copper on all these other things.

Having said that, I wouldn't project that a year from now or five years from now, our gross margin is going to be significantly more than it is today. I think the dynamics, all those things I just mentioned and so forth, will continue to put some downward pressure on gross margin percentage. We'll manage to offset that, maybe take it up 10 basis points here or there.

The real opportunity we have, I think from a bottom line margin standpoint, and I would suggest that where we are now at somewhat of a low point, partly because of the repositioning of the business. The business we bought from Power Solutions had a much, much lower operating profit margin than what we had and we've got our EES business with very depressed margins because of mining, oil and gas and the broader industrials that's off about a couple of hundred basis points from where it should be say in mid-cycle, if you will.

So I think as we're very well positioned as we get, I must say, even if it's not a tailwind, it's less of a headwind in that sector and get a little bit of increase in demand, we'll leverage the heck out of a little bit of revenue growth. We have a cost base that we continue to take various steps to right size. We've taken some costs out in Canada, Brazil, Continental Europe, some of the areas that have continued to be slow growth or have had major challenges like Brazil certainly has and Western Canada certainly has.

So, I feel good about our cost structure that we'll be able to grow the revenue base quite significantly without any significant change in the cost structures.

UNIDENTIFIED PARTICIPANT: That's great. Well, I think we're pretty much running out of time. So thank you.

TED DOSCH: Okay, thanks everyone.

Pears: the arch-goddess of the fruit pantheon, the inspiration of Cézanne, and to the untrained eye, dangerously similar to apples. As iPhone In Canada first reported, Apple has filed a notice of opposition against a meal planning app called Prepear for us... Pears: the arch-goddess of the fruit pantheon, the inspiration of Cézanne, and to the untrained...

Pears: the arch-goddess of the fruit pantheon, the inspiration of Cézanne, and to the untrained eye, dangerously similar to apples. As iPhone In Canada first reported, Apple has filed a notice of opposition against a meal planning app called Prepear for us...

Pears: the arch-goddess of the fruit pantheon, the inspiration of Cézanne, and to the untrained eye, dangerously similar to apples. As iPhone In Canada first reported, Apple has filed a notice of opposition against a meal planning app called Prepear for using a pear logo which is pear-shaped and pear-green. In a Change.org petition , Prepear lamented that, “Apple has opposed dozens of other trademark applications filed by small businesses with fruit related logos,” which have since been altered or replaced, because, “most small businesses cannot afford the tens of thousands of dollars it would cost to fight Apple.” Apple thought of fruit in 1976, and you can’t have it back. The Apple lawyers are fearsome, we know, and will battle government regulators no matter how long and arduous the path to victory . No fruit has escaped them : just over the past few months, they pursued apple-shaped diamond pendants , apple-flavored vape juice , and the Appleton, Wisconsin school district . They’ve tried to stop a digital music company attempting to brand itself as “Franki Pineapple” (the logo for which resembles a grenade ), arguing that , “while the word ‘apple’ and ‘pineapple’ do not have the same meaning, they are both the names of fruits, and thus convey a similar commercial impression.” In its notice of opposition against Prepear, Apple particularly takes issue with Prepear’s fruit-branded focus on health — exactly like Apple. “One of the categories highlighted on Apple’s Health app is Nutrition,” they offer, as one example, noting also that the Apple Watch monitors heart rates, and Apple provides software for healthcare providers. On top of consumers’ immediate association between Apple and health, Prepear’s pear, they argue, is likely to recall the Apple logo because just look at it. “Applicant’s Mark consists of a minimalistic fruit design with a right-angled leaf, which readily calls to mind Apple’s famous Apple Logo and creates a similar commercial impression, as shown in the following side-by-side comparison:” In short, the above pear is certain to baffle consumers. “The Apple Marks are so famous and instantly recognisable that the similarities in Applicant’s Mark will overshadow any differences and cause the ordinary consumer to believe that Applicant is related to, affiliated with or endorsed by Apple.” What if some disappointed consumer comes to Prepear to buy an overpriced laptop and leaves empty-handed? Think of the reputational damages! It’s a leap for me, but after inspecting Apple’s long history of filings, one can imagine how Apple might be blinded by its own fruit. Last year, they reportedly filed an objection against Norway’s Progress Party for using an apple, against Banana Computer and Banana Mobile , and Pear Technologies , which also branded itself with a pear. In their Change.org petition , Prepear, which claims to have only five staffers, says that the thousands of dollars wasted on litigation has already forced one layoff — but they’re not taking this lying down. “We feel a moral obligation to take a stand against Apple’s aggressive legal action against small businesses and fight for the right to keep our logo,” they write. “We are defending ourselves against Apple not only to keep our logo, but to send a message to big tech companies that bullying small businesses has consequences.” The Change.org petition, which currently has over 26,000 signatures, asks that Apple drop its “frivolous litigation” and “stop big tech companies from abusing their position of power by going after small businesses like ours who are already struggling due to the affects [sic] of Covid-19.” Can you tell an apple from a pear? The post appeared first on Gizmodo Australia . Related Stories Anjou Get a Lawsuit - Enclosure How to Get the Latest Apple Watch Beta Right Now The Best Wireless Headphones You Can Buy Right Now
